Together with William Tirebuck and George Rose, his friends from school days,<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=31.}}</ref> Caine applied himself to establishing Liverpool branches of the Shakespeare Society, and the [[Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=50.}}</ref> They called their own organisation Notes and Queries Society and held their meetings at the prominent [[Liverpool Royal Institution|Royal Institution]], Colquitt Street. Caine was president of the society and their meetings were reported in the Liverpool newspapers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Local News|work=Liverpool Mercury|date=5 February 1879}}</ref> The ‘Notes’ were often provided by [[John Ruskin]], [[William Morris]] and [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Tirebuck|1903|p=xv.}}</ref>
On 16 October 1874 [[Henry Irving]] wrote to Caine agreeing to his request to use his portrait in ''Stray Leaves'' a new monthly magazine he was launching.<ref>{{Harvnb|Stoker|1906|p=115.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=44.}}</ref> In his capacity as critic of the Liverpool ''Town Crier'', Caine attended the first night of ''[[Hamlet]]'' at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London]], on 31 October 1874, with Irving in the title role. Caine was enthralled by Irving's performance and after his enthusiastic review was published in the newspaper, he was asked to reprint it as a broad-sheet pamphlet, as it was of such a high quality.<ref>{{Harvnb|Stoker|1906|p=115.}}</ref>
Caine's first short story ''Max Wieland'' was published in the ''Liverpool Critic'' around 1874. A year later Caine became dramatic critic of the ''Spectator''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Day to Day in Liverpool|publisher=Liverpool Daily Post|date=14 May 1918|page=3}}</ref> Caine's long narrative poem, ''Geraldine'', appeared in print in March 1876. It was a completion of [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge|Coleridge's]] unfinished poem ''[[Christabel (poem)|Christabel]]''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=44.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=44.}}</ref>
The Caine family had moved into a larger house in 1873, at 59 South Chester Street, [[Toxteth]], where Caine shared a bedroom with his younger brother John, a shipping clerk.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=32.}}</ref> John contracted [[tuberculosis]] which he passed to his brother. By 1875 Caine had permanent lodgings in [[New Brighton, Merseyside|New Brighton]], spending weekends there "for the sake of his health".<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=52.}}</ref> Caine became increasingly unwell from the beginning of January 1877. In April the same year John, died from [[tuberculosis]], aged 21. Dangerously ill, Caine was terrified of suffering the same fate.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=55.}}</ref> He recovered, but the disease left him with permanent lung damage, and throughout his life he had attacks of [[bronchitis]]. In his 1913 novel ''The Woman Thou Gavest Me'', he describes Mary O’Neil dying of tuberculosis.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=353.}}</ref>
[[File:The shadow of a crime by Hall Caine.jpg|thumb|right|1895 Poster advertising ''The Shadow of a Crime''.]] [[Manchester City Council|Manchester Corporation]] had covertly been buying land for building the proposed [[Thirlmere Aqueduct]], intended to supply water to the city. When discovered, it outraged the local community. [[Thirlmere]], close to the centre of the Lake District, in an area, not only celebrated in the poetry of early conservationist [[William Wordsworth]] and fellow Lake poets, but also used as a summer residence by writers, amongst others.<ref>{{Harvnb|Ritvo|2009|pp=12, 102.}}</ref> In opposition to damming the lake at [[Thirlmere]] to form a reservoir, the first environmental group, Thirlmere Defence Association was formed in 1877.<ref>{{Harvnb|Ritvo|2009|pp=1–6.}}</ref> It was supported by the national press, Wordsworth's son and John Ruskin. Caine, incensed at what he perceived as a threat to his beloved Cumbria, joined the movement, initiating a Parliamentary petition.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=62.}}</ref> Thirlmere was to be the setting for his novel ''The Shadow of a Crime''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=62.}}</ref>
In response to his lecture ''The Supernatural in Shakespeare'',<ref>{{cite news|title=Notes and Queries. Professor Dowden on the study of Shakespere|work=Liverpool Mercury|date=10 July 1878|pages=8}}</ref> given in July 1878, in a meeting chaired by [[Edward Dowden|Professor Edward Dowden]], [[Matthew Arnold]] wrote him a long letter of praise. He was also praised by [[John Keats|Keats]]'s biographer, [[Richard Monckton Milnes, 1st Baron Houghton|Lord Houghton]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=58.}}</ref> The lecture appeared in ''Colburn's New Monthly Magazine'' in August 1879,<ref>{{cite news|title=The Magazines For September|work=Liverpool Mercury|date=3 September 1879|pages=6}}</ref>
Irving presided at a meeting of the Liverpool Notes and Queries Society in September 1878. At Irving's invitation, he travelled to London to attend Irving's first night at the Lyceum Theatre under his own management, presenting his new production of ''Hamlet'' with [[Ellen Terry]] as ''[[Ophelia]]'' on 30 December. It was at this time that Caine was introduced to Irving's business manager, [[Bram Stoker]], who was to become one of his closest friends.<ref>{{Harvnb|Foulkes|2008|p=55.}}</ref> Stoker was subsequently to dedicate his famous novel ''[[Dracula]]'' to Caine, under the [[nickname]] 'Hommy-Beg'.
In 1879 Caine edited a booklet of the papers presented to the Notes and Queries Society by [[William Morris]], [[Samuel Huggins]] and [[J. J. Stevenson|John J. Stevenson]] on the progress of public and professional thought on the treatment of ancient buildings which was described as "‘well worth reading".<ref>{{cite news|title=Literary Notices,|work=Liverpool Mercury|date=22 February 1879}}</ref><ref>The Restoration of Ancient Buildings. Papers by William Morris, Samuel Huggins, J. J. Stevenson, etc., edited by T. H. Hall Caine. Royal Institution, Liverpool. 1877. Crown 8vo. 50 pp.</ref> At the 1879 [[National Association for the Promotion of Social Science|Social Science Congress]] held in [[Manchester Town Hall]], Caine read his paper ''A New Phase of the Question of Architectural Restoration''. He spoke of the [[Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings]], its purpose, actions and achievements.<ref>{{cite news|title=Social Science Congress|work=Liverpool Mercury|date=7 October 1879|pages=7}}</ref> Caine had joined the society the previous year and remained a member for the rest of his life. One of the society's founders was [[William Morris]].
===Friendship with Francis Tumblety=== As a young man of 21 Caine encountered the self-proclaimed ‘Great American Doctor’, [[Francis Tumblety]], aged 43, after he set up at 177 Duke Street, Liverpool, offering herbal cure-all [[elixir]]s and [[Patent medicine]]s to the public, which he claimed were secrets of the [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indians]]. Tumblety posed at various times in his life as a surgeon, an officer in the federal army, and a gentleman.<ref>{{Harvnb| Curtis Jr.|2001|p=29.}}</ref> He always followed his name with "M.D." and used the title ‘Doctor’, without the supporting qualifications for which he was fined in [[Saint John, New Brunswick]] in 1860.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|p=93.}}</ref>
From September 1874, Tumblety was announcing his arrival in Liverpool by advertising in local newspapers, later including testimonials.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|pp=111–112.}}</ref> Following the death of Edward Hanratty in January 1875, the same night he took a spoon of medicine supplied by Tumblety, and action taken by William Carroll to sue Tumblety for £200 after allegedly publishing a false testimonial, Tumblety fled to London.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|pp=113–114.}}</ref> Many newspapers reported the stories and in the wake of this adverse publicity, Tumblety recruited Caine to edit his biography. Late January Tumblety wrote requesting Caine to obtain a quote for printing ten thousand copies in [[Liverpool]], telling of being betrayed by a supposed friend, and praising Caine for his genuine friendship.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|p=116.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb| Riordan |2009|p=148.}}</ref> After Caine forwarded his letters, he wrote on 1 February discussing the upcoming biography and enclosed a letter supposedly originating from the [[Isle of Wight]], by [[Napoleon III]].<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|p=114.}}</ref> The following day the first advert for the upcoming [[pamphlet]] appeared in the ''Liverpool Mercury''.<ref>{{Harvnb| Riordan |2009|p=148.}}</ref> Tumblety changed lodgings, initially missing an urgent telegram from Caine indicating there was a problem with the publication. His response was to tell Caine to stop until he saw the proofs. Tumblety offered to pay for Caine to visit him in London to discuss the pamphlet, his letter dated 16 February indicating Caine had taken up the offer.<ref>{{Harvnb| Riordan |2009|p=149.}}</ref> He told a friend that his visit to Tumblety was "arduous".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=29.}}</ref> A spate of correspondence relating to the publication ensued, Tumblety supplying Caine with names of notable people to be included in the pamphlet, along with money for printing and advertising. Tumblety later wrote of disputes with the printer. Claiming to be too ill to send money, he sent Caine a printer's bill for payment. Tumblety had hired an assistant who read the proofs to him. The pamphlet entitled ''Passages from the Life of Dr Francis Tumblety'', and the fourth of Tumblety's biographies, was published in March 1875.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|p=116.}}</ref>
Tumblety wrote to Caine in April 1875 that he was contemplating manufacturing his pills in London, and required a partner to share the profits, telling Caine to approach Liverpool chemists as proposed outlets.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|p=118.}}</ref> Caine had declined a further invitation to London, but Tumblety persisted with his invites to join him in London, later made by telegram, additionally inviting him on a planned trip to [[America]].<ref>{{Harvnb| Riordan |2009|p=150.}}</ref> Around the time Alfred Thomas Heap was hanged in [[Kirkdale, Liverpool|Kirkdale Gaol, Liverpool]], for an abortion-related death, Tumblety, who had been arrested in 1857 for selling abortion drugs, disappeared. Caine made enquiries as to his whereabouts.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|p=120.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=An Indian Herb Doctor – Curious Case|work=Liverpool Mercury|date=12 October 1857|page=2}}</ref> Briefly Tumblety set up offices in Union Passage, [[Birmingham]]. His correspondence turned menacing, demanding money from Caine.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|p=123.}}</ref> Tumblety left London for New York City in August 1876. Failing to entice Caine to join him, he followed months later with a pleading letter from San Francisco, after which there is no record of any further contact.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|p=128.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb| Riordan |2009|p=152.}}</ref>
===Rossetti years=== Caine delivered a series of three lectures on [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]]'s work and the [[Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood]] movement between November 1878 and March 1879, afterwards combining them into an essay which was printed in ''Colburn's New Monthly Magazine''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=63, 68.}}</ref> Caine sent a copy of the magazine to the poet Rossetti, who by that time had become a virtual recluse and was "ravaged by years of addiction to chloral and too much whisky".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=69–71.}}</ref>
[[File:Hall Caine and Rossetti.png|thumb|Dante Gabriel Rossetti walking to and fro while Hall Caine reads his lectures out loud during their stay in a farmhouse at St John's in the Vale, Cumbria.]] Rossetti wrote his first letter to Caine on 29 July 1879. This letter was the first of nearly two hundred in quick succession.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|pp=59–62.}}</ref> Around this time Caine's father was badly injured in an accident at work and Caine took responsibility for supporting his parents and siblings.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=103.}}</ref> Early in 1880 he wrote ''Stones Crying Out'', a short book on the restoration of old buildings. Two of the chapters were papers he had read at the [[Social Science Congress]] and [[Liverpool Central Library|Liverpool Library]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|2000|pp=25, 36, 110.}}</ref> Rossetti introduced Caine to [[Ford Madox Brown]], who was at the time working on ''[[The Manchester Murals]]''. Following his visit to write an article on Brown's frescoes in July 1880 they became friends. On a later visit Caine accepted Brown's invitation to sit for one of the figures while he was working on ''The Expulsion of the Danes from Manchester'', the third fresco.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=88, 105;}}</ref> On another visit he modelled for ''Crabtree watching the Transit of Venus A.D. 1639'', the fifth fresco to be painted.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=152.}}</ref> Caine and Rossetti eventually met in September 1880 when Caine visited Rossetti in his home at 16 [[Cheyne Walk]], [[Chelsea, London]], where he lived "in shabby splendour".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=91.}}</ref>
The strain of overworking was affecting Caine's health and in 1881, deciding to focus on his literary career, he left his job at Bromley & Son and went to [[St John's in the Vale]], Cumbria.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=148.}}</ref> Before long Rossetti wrote that he too was ill and asked Caine to go to London planning to return to Cumbria with him. By the time Caine arrived in London Rossetti had changed his mind and instead Caine became Rossetti's housemate.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=150.}}</ref> Early in September, persuaded by friends and family Rossetti spent a month with Caine at St John's in the Vale, accompanied by [[Fanny Cornforth]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Waugh|2011|p=228.}}</ref> Whilst there, Caine recited a local myth to Rossetti. The myth was to become the inspiration for his first novel ''The Shadow of a Crime''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|pp=176–177.}}</ref> He was also delivering weekly lectures in Liverpool.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|pp=173, 190.}}</ref>
Caine negotiated the acquisition of Rossetti's largest painting ''[[Dante's Dream|Dante's Dream of the Death of Beatrice]]'' by Liverpool's [[Walker Art Gallery]],<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=149}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The sale of ‘Dante's Dream at the time of the Death of Beatrice’ to the Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool: The Correspondence between D. G. Rossetti and T. H. Caine.|url=https://www.academia.edu/3176513/The_sale_of_Dante_s_Dream_at_the_time_of_the_Death_of_Beatrice_to_the_Walker_Art_Gallery_Liverpool_The_Correspondence_between_D._G._Rossetti_and_T._H._Caine|accessdate=23 October 2016}}</ref> representing the painter at its installation in November 1881.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=109, 133.}}</ref> In January 1882 Caine's [[anthology]] ''Sonnets of Three Centuries'' was published.
After Rossetti "had an attack of paralysis on one side", his medical adviser, Mr John Marshall, recommended a change of air.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rossetti|1895|pp=384, 387.}}</ref> Architect [[John Pollard Seddon|John Seddon]] offered Rossetti the use of Westcliffe Bungalow at [[Birchington-on-Sea|Birchington]], Kent.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rossetti|1895|pp=388, 395.}}</ref> Caine eventually persuaded Rossetti to make the trip to Birchington, and they both arrived on 4 February 1882, accompanied by Caine's sister and Rossetti's nurse. Caine stayed with Rossetti until Rossetti's death on Easter Sunday, 1882.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1882|pp=294–295.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=88, 141.}}</ref>
==Start of literary career== [[File:Hall Caine Vanity Fair 2 July 1896.jpg|thumb|right|<center>''The Manxman''<br>Caine as caricatured in ''[[Vanity Fair (British magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', July 1896</center>]] From 1882 Caine was employed as a leader-writer on the ''Liverpool Mercury'' and was given free rein as to the subject and number of articles he wrote.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=82.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=252.}}</ref> This gave him the opportunity to attend and review numerous first nights at the London theatres.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=34.}}</ref> One review angered actor-playwright [[Wilson Barrett]] and he demanded a meeting with Caine.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=255.}}</ref> Barrett concluding his complaint added "I think you could write a play, and if someday you should hit on a subject suitable to me, I shall be glad if you will let me hear of it".<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=37.}}</ref>
Caine's ''Cobwebs of Criticism: A Review of the First Reviewers of the Lake, Satanic and Cockney Schools'' was published in 1883. It began as a series of Liverpool lectures exposing unjustified reviews of poets [[Lord Byron|Byron]], [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge|Coleridge]], [[Leigh Hunt|Hunt]], [[John Keats|Keats]], [[Percy Bysshe Shelley|Shelley]], [[Robert Southey|Southey]] and [[William Wordsworth|Wordsworth]] that were written during their lifetimes<ref>{{Harvnb|Waller|2006|p=133.}}</ref>
[[File:Mary Hall Caine.jpg|thumb|left|Mary Hall Caine by Alfred Ellis]] [[File:Portrait of Hall Caine.jpg|thumb|left|Hall Caine, by H. S. Mendelssohn]] Returning to London after Rossetti's death, Caine moved into 18 [[Inns of Chancery|Clement's Inn]], in July 1882, sharing rooms with his academic friend [[Eric Sutherland Robertson|Eric Robertson]], where they often hosted intellectual gatherings.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=153.}}</ref> They had evening meals delivered from a nearby coffee shop in [[Clare Market]], which were brought by two teenage girls; one being thirteen year old Mary Chandler, who was to eventually marry Caine.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=258.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=153.}}</ref> Months later, Mary's stepfather, and the other girl's father confronted Caine and Robertson demanding marriage, claiming the girls had been ‘ruined’. According to Caine's biographer, nothing more than 'a bit of flirting' had taken place.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=153.}}</ref> The [[Age of consent#Reforms in the 19th and 20th century|age of consent]] for girls was thirteen, raised from twelve in 1875. Robertson married the older girl and moved to Kent.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=154.}}</ref> Refusing to marry, Caine went to Liverpool to deliver lectures, returning to London early December 1882.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=155.}}</ref> Upon Caine's return Mary's stepfather abandoned her at Clement's Inn. Caine's choices were to leave Mary on the street, marry or adopt her.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=259.}}</ref> Until she could start school after the Christmas holidays Mary lived at Clements Inn, she had received little education as a child.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=155.}}</ref> Caine's visiting friends assumed he and Mary had married as Robertson had.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=83.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=159.}}</ref> Mary was sent to [[Sevenoaks]] where she stayed for six months being taught either at a private school or privately by a governess, financed by Caine.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=159–160.}}</ref>
At the end of October 1883, with enough money to last about four months Caine, accompanied by Mary, went to the [[Isle of Wight]] where he rented Vectis Cottage, close to the cliffs and sea near [[Sandown]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|pp=82–83.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=168.}}</ref> There he set to work writing his first novel ''The Shadow of a Crime''. Inspired by his Cumbrian heritage the plot was based on one of the oldest legends of the Lake District, told to him by his grandfather, Ralph Hall.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1905|p=ix.}} Bram Stoker Introduction to Hall Caine, Shadow of a Crime</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Jerome|1897|p=59.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=283.}}</ref> In it he uses the [[Cumbrian dialect]] that he had listened to and spoke during his childhood.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1905|p=ix.}} Bram Stoker Introduction to Hall Caine, Shadow of a Crime</ref> When he had finished he moved back to London. Living in rooms on the fourth floor of New Court, in [[Lincoln's Inn]], he re-wrote it.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=88.}}</ref> After running as a serial in the ''Liverpool Mercury'', Caine's novel was published in February 1885, by [[Chatto & Windus]], and serialised in several newspapers.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=174–175.}}</ref> His reputation was immediately established, along with a foremost place among the novelists of the day.<ref>{{cite news|title=Illustrated London News|date=2 April 1887|page=28}}</ref> He was later invited to write the story of writing ''The Shadow of a Crime'', which after its appearance in ''the Idler'' was published in 1894 in ''My First Book''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=83.}}</ref> After the publication of Caine's first novel, Mary created a series of scrapbooks containing items relating to his public life.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=176.}} Now held in the Manx Museum, [[Douglas, Isle of Man|Douglas]]</ref>
Mary and Caine's son, [[Gordon Hall Caine|Ralph Hall]], was born in their rented house Yarra, Worseley Road, [[Hampstead]] on 15 August 1884. The following month they moved to live in Aberleigh Lodge, Red House Lane, [[Bexleyheath]], next door to William Morris' [[Red House (London)|Red House]], where they remained until 1889.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Globe|date=23 November 1889|page=6}}</ref>
Caine had many friends in London's elite artistic and intellectual circles.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=36.}}</ref> As a friend of Stoker and Irving for many years he became a regular at Irving's [[Beefsteak Club|Beefsteak Room]] gatherings at the Lyceum, presided over by [[Ellen Terry]], where he became acquainted with the [[Edward VII|Prince of Wales (later Edward VII)]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=164.}}</ref> At one supper, where the only other guest was composer [[Alexander Mackenzie (composer)|Alexander Mackenzie]], Caine breaking the rules, brought his son Ralph with him.<ref>{{Harvnb| Storey |2012|pp=143–144.}}</ref>
In order to make essential money and acquire exposure in America, disregarding the advice of his friends, Caine's short novel ''[[She's All The World To Me]]'', was published in New York, in 1885 by [[Harper & Brothers]]. The first of his novels to be set on the Isle of Man. Under [[American copyright law]]s the book's copyright was forfeited to Harper and Brothers, a situation unforeseen by Caine, he was incensed.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=165, 178.}}</ref> The novel was never released outside America. Caine recycled much of the material from the book in his later works, particularly in ''The Deemster''. It is likely that the story is Caine's 1883 ''Liverpool Mercury'' weekly serial entitled ''Danny Fayle''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=178.}}</ref> At the time Caine and the Mercury's editor John Lovell attempted to publish the serial as a book but were unable to find a publisher.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=165.}}</ref>
Set in the contrasting locations of the Vale of Newlands in the Lake District and [[Victorian London]],<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=93.}}</ref> ''A Son of Hagar'', Caine's third novel was written in 1885-86 and published in 1886 by Chatto and Windus.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1905|p=vi.}} Bram Stoker Introduction to Hall Caine, Son of Hagar</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=92.}}</ref> Begun in collaboration with [[Robert Williams Buchanan|Robert Buchanan]], their partnership was discontinued early on after discovering they did not work well together.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1905|p=vi.}} Bram Stoker Introduction to Hall Caine, Son of Hagar</ref> Dealing with the theme of [[illegitimacy in fiction|illegitimacy]], Caine has written a story close to his own life.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=181.}}</ref> The opening scene is set in Victorian London police court where a girl is charged with attempted suicide after she and her illegitimate baby had been dragged from the Thames, a scene he could well have witnessed while working as reporter.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|pp=259–261.}}</ref> Later Caine attempted to suppress ''A Son of Hagar'' from both of the Collected Editions of his novels. Licensed to Thomas Nelson in 1907 by Chatto, the novel was printed in the ''Nelson Library''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=178.}}</ref>
In 1886 Mary and Caine travelled to Scotland to watch Irving when he was on tour in Edinburgh where they covertly married on 3 September under Scottish law by declaration before witnesses. Mary became a devoted wife, reading all his work, advising and criticising when appropriate and was his first secretary.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=184,205.}}</ref>
Two of Caine's sonnets, ''Where Lies the Land!'' and ''After Sunset'', were included in [[William Sharp (writer)|William Sharp]]'s 1886 anthology ''Sonnets of this Century''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sharp|first1=William|title=Sonnets of this century|url=https://archive.org/details/sonnetsthiscent01shargoog|publisher=London, W. Scott, limited|accessdate=10 June 2017|date=1886}}</ref> Publisher [[Walter Scott]] engaged Eric Robertson, Caine's former roommate, to edit a series entitled ''Great Writers''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=185.}}</ref> Aware of the study Caine had already made of Coleridge, Robertson asked Caine to contribute a brief [[biography]] of the poet to the series. In three weeks Caine wrote ''Life of Coleridge'', published in 1887.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=120.}}</ref> November the same year ''[[The Deemster]]'' was published in three volumes by Chatto & Windus. It was set in 18th century Isle of Man, where the title of [[Deemster]] is given to the Island's judges. The plot includes the story of a fatal fight, with the body being taken out to sea only to float back to land the next day. It ran to more than fifty English editions and was translated into every major European language.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=55.}}</ref> Caine sent a copy of the novel to [[Wilson Barrett]] as he suited the main character, then set to work adapting his novel into a stage version called Ben-my-Chree, Manx for 'Girl of my Heart'.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=120.}}</ref> Irving, after reading the book, saw potential in it, himself playing the Bishop.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=48.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|pp=348–349.}}</ref> The play opened at the Princess Theatre on 17 May 1888 and ran for a profitable nine weeks.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=47.}}</ref> It was a popular staple on Barratt's provincial and international tours for several years afterwards and successfully produced by others to whom he licensed the rights.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=47.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1905|p=121.}}</ref> An appreciative Caine acknowledged Barratt's substantial contribution by naming him co-writer.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1908|p=346.}}</ref>
==Middle years== [[File:Caine's study.jpg|thumb|Caine's study at Hawthorns, 1889, drawn by A. Tucker. The bust of Shakespeare on the desk originally belonged to Rossetti. The chair, designed and made for Caine by William Morris, is on the left. On the right, a carved oak chair from Cheyne Walk.]]
===First visit to Iceland=== The first title published by [[Heinemann (publisher)|Heinemann]] was Caine's 1890 three-volume novel ''[[The Bondman (novel)|The Bondman]]'', a plot of revenge and romance set in the late 18th century Isle of Man and [[Iceland]]. It commences with the story of a seaman who marries the daughter of Iceland's Governor-General, abandoning her before the birth of their child.<ref name="EliotRose2009">{{cite book|last1=Eliot|first1=Simon|last2=Rose|first2=Jonathan|title=A Companion to the History of the Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R8Pfs146nUAC&pg=PA343|accessdate=1 January 2013|date=2009-04-06|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781405192781|page=343.}}</ref> Between June and November 1889 it was serialised in the ''Isle of Man Times'', ''General Advertiser'' and several provincial newspapers.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|pp=91,227.}}</ref> Accompanied by Mary, Caine made a research visit to Iceland in August 1889, during which he made a seventy-mile round day trip from [[Reykavik]] to [[Krysuvik]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1905|pp=ix-x.}}Bram Stoker Introduction to Hall Caine, The Bondman</ref> [[William Heinemann]] was so pleased with initial sales, eventually selling almost half a million copies, that he named his company's [[telegraphic address]] after the novel's main character, "Sunlocks".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=202.}}</ref>
===Cumbria=== Caine leased Castlerigg Cottage in [[Keswick, Cumbria|Keswick]] in 1888. The following year Caine bought Hawthorns out of part of his earnings from ''Ben-my-Chree''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Sherard|1895|p=92.}}</ref> Hawthorns was a small square-built stone house on the Penrith Road, a mile outside Keswick, overlooking [[Bassenthwaite Lake]] and Derwentwater. Caine also rented a [[Pied-à-terre]] at Albert Mansions, Victoria Street, London. Hawthorns was close to Chesnut Cottage that [[Percy Bysshe Shelley|Shelley]] had rented in 1811 and [[Greta Hall]] home of the poets [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge|Coleridge]] and [[Robert Southey|Southey]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=192–193,196–197.}}</ref> The house had ten acres of land where Caine kept two ponies he had transported from Iceland.<ref>{{cite news|title=Literary Gossip|work= The Globe|date=23 November 1889|page=6}}</ref> Mary learned to make butter and cheese. The Caines lived at Hawthorns for four years.
Around 1890 Caine published a magazine serial called ''Drink: A Love Story on a Great Question''. This was about the same time as [[Bram Stoker]] began his notes for his ''[[Dracula]]'' novel. Stoker and Caine were lifetime literary friends. They shared an interest in [[mesmerism]]. ''Drink'' contains a number of similarities to Stoker's novel.<ref>{{Harvnb|Skall|2016|p=296.}}</ref> In 1906 ''Drink'' was published by [[George Newnes]], and illustrated by expatriate Italian American illustrator and painter [[Cyrus Cuneo]]. It was described in the ''Manchester Guardian'' as ‘a rather gruesome love story’.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=314.}}</ref> The story is of a girl who inherits a taste for alcohol from her father and is put on the road to recovery by hypnotic influence. Two hundred thousand copies of the book had been sold in England by the time the American edition was published by [[D. Appleton & Company|Appleton]] in 1907.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hall Caine and Hypnotism.; A Pup's Philosophy|work=The New York Times|date=26 January 1907}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=125.}}</ref>
===Banning of ''Mahomet''=== Caine's ''Mahomet'' is a four-act historical drama based on the life of [[Muhammad]], the [[prophet]] of [[Islam]], written in 1890 for the actor-manager [[Henry Irving]]. In Autumn 1889 Irving presented a copy of [[Henri de Bornier]]'s new play ''Mahomet'' to Caine, translated into English by [[Bram Stoker]]'s wife, Florence.<ref>{{Harvnb| Tetens|2015|p=107.}}</ref> Irving had been granted the English rights by [[Jules Claretie]], director of France's [[Comédie-Française|Théâtre Français]] and he asked Caine to revise it for staging at the Lyceum.<ref>{{Harvnb| Tetens|2015|p=53.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb| Foulkes|2008|p=49.}}</ref> The French government stopped Bornier's play on 22 March 1890, partly due to the intervention of the Ottoman Sultan [[Abdul Hamid II]].<ref>{{Harvnb| Tetens|2015|pp=115–120.}}</ref> Caine called the play's plot "false to history, untrue to character, Western in thought and Parisian in sentiment''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hall Caine, A Literary Causerie|work=The Speaker|date=4 October 1890}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb| Foulkes|2008|p=53.}}</ref> He continued with his own version that concentrated on Muhammad's flight from Mecca and his triumphant return from Medina years later.<ref>{{Harvnb| Foulkes|2008|p=54.}}</ref> Scenes were handwritten by Caine and subsequently reviewed by Irving after Stoker had them typed. Reviewed pages were returned with Irving's edits and often Stoker's suggestions.<ref>{{Harvnb| Tetens|2015|p=114.}}</ref> On 20 June a piece appeared in the French ''[[Journal des débats]]'' soon followed by a longer piece in ''[[The Pall Mall Gazette]]'' connecting Bornier's ''Mahomet'' with Irving's English production.<ref>{{Harvnb| Foulkes|2008|p=57.}}</ref> [[Abdullah Quilliam|William Henry (Abdullah) Quilliam]] orchestrated protests. In common with Caine he was of Manx descent, raised in Liverpool and had visited Morocco. Converting to Islam, Quilliam set up Britain's first mosque and was made Sheikh al-Islam for the British Isles by Abdul Hamid II. Rumour that the play would be produced in London caused unrest in Britain's Muslim communities, threatened British rule in parts of India and strained the nation's relations with the Ottoman Empire. It was banned by the [[Lord Chamberlain]], [[Edward Bootle-Wilbraham, 1st Earl of Lathom]] in his capacity as licenser of stage plays.<ref>{{Harvnb| Foulkes|2008|p=59.}}</ref> Lathom's intervention was unusual, illustrating the high level of concern by the British government.<ref>{{Harvnb| Tetens|2015|p=196.}}</ref> Caine's completed play was accepted by [[Edward Smith Willard]] for production in America. Influenced by Renan's ''Life of Christ'' he spent the remainder of 1890 hastily writing his own version. Dissatisfied with the result he refused to publish the book, despite being offered three thousand pounds for it in 1894.<ref>{{Harvnb| Sherard|1895|p=92.}}</ref>
===Morocco=== Caine travelled to [[Tangier]], [[Morocco]], for three weeks In March 1890, researching [[Muslim]] and [[Jewish]] life.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=114.}}</ref> Disregarding the advice of British consular officials Caine explored the Kasbah alone on foot at all hours of the day and night.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=209.}}</ref> Returning to Tangier in Spring 1891 to pick up local colour for his next novel ''The Scapegoat'', he suffered an attack of [[malarial fever]].<ref>{{cite news|title=London Correspondence|work=Birmingham Daily Post|date=6 July 1891|pages=4}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Caine|first1=Hall|title=The Scapegoat|date=1899|publisher=P.F. Collier & Son|location=New York|page=v}}</ref> Caine became the house-guest of [[Ion Perdicaris]], who arranged Caine's nursing until he was sufficiently recovered to return to England.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pall Mall Gazette Office|work= Pall Mall Gazette |date=2 May 1891|page=6}}</ref> In July of the same year ''The Little Manx Nation'' was published. It was originally delivered in the form of three lectures on the history of the Isle of Man which were given at the [[Royal Institution]], London on 22 and 29 January and 4 February 1891.<ref>{{cite news|title=Royal Institution of Great Britain|work= St. James's Gazette |date=19 January 1891|page=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Pall Mall Gazette Office|work= Pall Mall Gazette |date=5 February 1891|page=6}}</ref> The book is dedicated to Manx poet [[Thomas Edward Brown]], who supplied Caine with information on Manx legends and ballads.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=212.}}</ref>
''The Scapegoat '' was written at Hawthorns immediately after Caine returned home from Morocco, while he was still impeded by malaria.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Caine|first1=Hall|title= The Scapegoat|date=1899|publisher=P.F. Collier & Son|location=New York|page=v}}</ref> First serialised in ''The Illustrated London News '' between July and October 1891, and then in ''[[The Penny Illustrated Paper]]'' between October 1891 January 1892. In the story, little Naomi is deaf and dumb and blind. Her mother is dead. She lives with her father, in Israel's house. As Israel changes his ways to become a better person Naomi starts to regain her lost senses. The novel was published in two volumes in September 1891 by William Heinemann, and simultaneously in Europe, America and Canada.<ref>{{Harvnb| Allen|1997|p=434.}}</ref> Set in Morocco in the last years of the [[Abd al-Rahman of Morocco|Sultan Abd er-Rahman]], it exposed [[anti-Semitic]] persecution and was described as a ‘scathing indictment of Moroccan tyranny’.<ref>{{cite news|title=London Correspondence|work=Birmingham Daily Post|date=6 July 1891|pages=4}}</ref> The book was praised by ‘the most intelligent and influential members of the respectable Jewish community in London’.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mr Hall Caine's Mission to Russia|work=Illustrated London News|date=10 October 1891|page=8}}</ref> Caine's Connections with the [[British Jewish community]] extended back to Caine's youth. Novelist [[Israel Zangwill]], enlisted Caine in the [[Zionist movement]].<ref>{{Harvnb| Tetens|2015|p=139.}}</ref> ''The Scapegoat'' brought Caine a considerable correspondence, mainly because of its pro-Jewish stance.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=211.}}</ref> At this time Caine and Mary's second son, [[Derwent Hall Caine|Derwent]] was born on 12 September 1891.
===Mission to Russia=== Following the publication of ''The Scapegoat'', Caine was approached by [[Hermann Adler]], the Chief [[Rabbi]] and chairman of the Russo-Jewish Committee. Jews were fleeing Russia due to the [[Anti-Jewish pogroms in the Russian Empire|pogroms]] and resulting atrocities happening there.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mr Hall Caine's Mission to Russia|work=Pall Mall Gazette|date=25 September 1891|pages=5}}</ref> Adler, certain no [[Jew]] would be allowed entry, requested Caine go to Russia and Poland on behalf of the committee. Caine's plans to depart for Russia after Christmas 1891 were delayed until 15 June 1892 due to famine and riots there.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=214–215,217.}}</ref> Caine funded the trip himself, refusing subsidies offered by the committee. He carried Adler's letter, in [[Hebrew]], to present to the rabbis in the various towns on his journey, which "secured him everywhere a most hospitable reception" and for protection against the Russian authorities Caine carried a letter from [[Lord Salisbury]], then Prime Minister.<ref>{{Harvnb| Sherard|1895|p=93.}}</ref> Caine managed to visit several Jewish communities in the [[Pale of Settlement]] but got no further than the frontier towns as many were dying due to a cholera outbreak. Fearing he was to suffer the same fate he returned to London, in time to attend [[Alfred, Lord Tennyson| Lord Alfred Tennyson's]] funeral in October 1892.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=222.}}</ref> Caine remained in London after the funeral working on three novellas ''Cap'n Davey's Honeymoon'', ''The Last Confession'' and ''The Blind Mother'', published in 1893 as one volume entitled ''Cap'n Davey's Honeymoon''. The book was edited by and dedicated to Stoker. At his suggestion, the last part of the title story was rewritten and ''The Last Confession'' was added.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=222.}}</ref> Set in Morocco, ''The Last Confession'' is based on Rossetti's blank-verse poem of the same name.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1901|p=125.}}</ref> [[File:Caine cartoon.jpg|thumb|Cartoon of Caine by [[Harry Furniss]]]]
===Isle of Man=== For the purpose of writing [[The Manxman (novel)|''The Manxman'']] Caine rented [[Greeba Castle]] for six months, a [[Crenellation|castellated]] house in the Isle of Man overlooking the [[Douglas, Isle of Man|Douglas]] to [[Peel, Isle of Man|Peel]] road.<ref>{{Harvnb|Norris|1947|p=9.}}</ref> It was this book, published as one volume in August 1894 by Heinemann, that ended the outdated system of three-volume novels.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1905|p=vi.}} Bram Stoker Introduction to Hall Caine, The Manxman</ref> It is the story of Pete, a fisherman, considered by Kate's father as too poor to marry her. Pete leaves to make his fortune, and is reported dead. Kate falls in love with Philip, Pete's cousin and friend. Pete returns, creating a dilemma. The character of Pete was based on the Peel fishermen Caine mixed with and Joseph Mylchreest, a Manxman who made his fortune diamond mining in South Africa.<ref>{{Harvnb|Norris|1947|p=9.}}</ref> Caine took full advantage of the subsequent Press attention. He was photographed and interviewed for the monthly magazines.<ref>{{Harvnb|Norris|1947|p=13.}}</ref> The British sales of ''The Manxman'' totalled nearly 400,000.<ref>{{Harvnb|Norris|1947|p=7.}}</ref> It was translated into twelve languages, selling over half a million copies by 1913.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=231.}}</ref> While in London in June and July 1984, Caine wrote a dramatic version of ''The Manxman'', with Philip as the main character. Caine offered it to [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]], who refused it as being unlikely to appeal to the [[Haymarket Theatre]] audiences.<ref>{{Harvnb| Sherard|1895|p=94.}}</ref> On 22 August 1894, three weeks after the book was published, Wilson Barrett's adaptation opened at the [[Grand Theatre, Leeds]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Kenyon|1901|p=121.}}</ref> Caine bought the Greeba Castle estate in 1896 with part of his earnings from ''The Manxman''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Caine|1905|p=vi.}} Bram Stoker Introduction to Hall Caine, The Manxman</ref> His rented London home, 48 Ashley Gardens, in one of five red-brick Victorian mansion blocks adjacent to [[Westminster Cathedral]], was changed to 2 [[Whitehall Court]] between [[Whitehall]] and the [[Victoria Embankment]].
Caine wrote a guidebook entitled ''The Little Man Island: Scenes and Specimen Days in the Isle of Man'' for the 1894 tourist season. Published by the [[Isle of Man Steam Packet Company]] it comprises a mixture of descriptions, pictures and advertising. At the end of the 19th century the Isle of Man was a popular tourist destination, a result of the [[Wakes Week]]s, when Lancashire mills and factories closed for holidays.<ref>{{Harvnb| Belchem |2000|p=223.}} Volume 5</ref> To meet growing demand the [[Isle of Man Steam Packet Company]] purchased new steamers to bring many thousands of tourists to Douglas from Liverpool. The Isle of Man Advertising Committee was set up in 1894 under the Advertising Rate Act.<ref>{{Harvnb| Kermode |2001 |p=20.}}</ref> A group of bankers, local businessmen and developers built new hotels, boarding houses and entertainment venues. They formed a Committee publicising the Isle of Man as a holiday resort, opening an office in London with Caine's brother in charge.<ref>{{Harvnb| Norris |1947 |p=8.}}</ref> When Caine wrote the Deemster in six weeks at a boarding house on the Douglas esplanade he saw these developments. He believed that the Island's economic prosperity lay in developing this trade.<ref>{{Harvnb| Norris |1947 |p=52.}}</ref> The success of Caine's novels set in the Isle of Man boosted the tourist trade.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=282.}}</ref> [[Tynwald Day]], the island's national day, became better known both in England and America because of his novels.<ref>{{Harvnb| Norris |1947 |p=9.}}</ref> Caine and Greeba Castle became a visitor attraction.<ref>{{Harvnb| Norris |1947 |pp=15–16.}}</ref> Cruising around Great Britain aboard the Royal yacht, [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|King Edward VII]] and [[Alexandra of Denmark|Queen Alexandra]] visited the Isle of Man, in August 1902.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Advertiser|location= Adelaide WA|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/4884865|date=2 October 1902}}</ref> They were the first British monarchs to set foot on Manx soil.<ref>{{Harvnb| Belchem |2000|p=232.}} Volume 5</ref> The King had read most of Caine's works and through reading them he wanted to visit the island.<ref>{{cite news|title=The King in the Isle of Man,|work= The Bedfordshire Advertiser |date=29 August 1902}}</ref> The Queen enjoyed Caine's Manx novels and was interested to see where his characters lived.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=287.}}</ref> The royal party enjoyed Caine's hospitality.<ref>{{Harvnb| Lee |1927|p=111.}}</ref> He was invited to join the royal couple on their yacht and to accompany them on their tour of the island the following day.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=289.}}</ref>
===Canadian copyright=== At a time [[Copyright law of Canada|copyrights in Canada]] were governed by British laws and legal framework the Canadian Government was attempting to enact their 1889 Copyright Bill. Canadian publishers sought to exclude competition from the United States.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=120.}}</ref> Collection of duty on imported foreign reprints of British copyright books was to be stopped after 27 March 1895.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=121.}}</ref><ref>{{cite wikisource|title=An Act to impose a duty on Foreign Reprints of British Copyright Works|last=|first=|year=|publisher=|page=|wspage=|scan=}}</ref> This situation, named the Canadian copyright question, caused concern to the British Government and they involved both [[the Copyright Association]] and the [[Society of Authors]], asking them to comment.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=122.}}</ref> During the ongoing discussions Caine maintained high profile, his interventions changing the course of the debate.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=126.}}</ref> Publishers in American recognised the threat of their market being flooded with cheap Canadian reprints on which no copyright fees would be paid.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=127.}}</ref> Proposed by Caine, the Society of Authors passed a unanimous vote, on 25 February 1895, against the [[Copyright Act of Canada|Canadian Copyright Act]]. Caine suggested "all authors should bind together to oppose the passing of the Act".<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=124.}}</ref> The Society sent a petition to the Marquess of Rippon, signed by over 1500 mainly authors and publishers, requesting Queen Victoria withhold assent of the Canadian Copyright Bill.<ref>{{cite news|title=British Authors and Canadian Copyright|work= London Evening Standard|date=21 March 1895|page=2}}</ref> If passed, there would be nothing preventing other colonies asking for the same, threatening authors with the loss of the whole Colonial market.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Society of Authors|work= London Evening Standard|date=26 February 1895|page=2}}</ref> The Society of Authors invited Caine to act as their representative in Canada and to negotiate with the Canadian Government on the 1889 Canadian Act.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=127.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The Attack on Signor Crispi|work= London Evening Standard|date=20 July 1895|page=7}}</ref> Similarly Frederick Richard Daldy represented the Copyright Association.<ref>{{cite wikisource|chapter=Daldy, Frederick Francis|wslink=Men-at-the-Bar|plaintitle=Men-at-the-Bar|last=|first=|year=|publisher=|page=|wspage=|scan=}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Alexander|2010|p=252.}}</ref> [[Edmund Leslie Newcombe|Edmund Newcome]], the Canadian Deputy Minister of Justice, eventually visited England in August 1895 to address the Canadian copyright problem, after his plans to visit had been postponed multiple times.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=127.}}</ref> Newcombe, instructed only to meet with the government, met with [[Joseph Chamberlain]], Secretary of State for the Colonies, in London to begin work on a new draft copyright bill. The Copyright Association and the Society of Authors were kept informed of proceedings.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=128.}}</ref>
===First visit to the United States and Canada=== Caine arrived in New York 25 September 1895, accompanied by his wife Mary and eldest son Ralph, where they were met by his New York publisher [[William Henry Appleton|William Appleton]], an active in the struggle for an [[international copyright]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=242–243.}}</ref> He carried with him a letter of introduction to the Government of Canada from Chamberlain.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=128.}}</ref> On the street he was mobbed by fans.<ref>{{Harvnb|Stoker|1906|pp=141–142.}}</ref> The following month Caine reached Canada, where he met with leading members of the publishing trade. He had long discussions with the Canadian Prime Minister [[Mackenzie Bowell]] and the Canadian Minister of Justice [[Charles Tupper]] in Ottawa. At the request of the Canadian Copyright Association Caine went to Toronto where he had talks with the Toronto publishers.<ref>{{Harvnb|Seville |2006|p=129.}}</ref> Caine resolved the dispute between the Canadian publishers, the Canadian Copyright Association and English authors. The proposed solution, that Canadian publishers would have the right to republish copyright works that had not been published in Canada within sixty days of publication elsewhere, was incorporated into the draft copyright bill. On 25 November 1895 Caine presented the draft bill at the Ottawa copyright conference where all parties agreed to it.<ref>{{cite book|title=Full text of "Conference on the copyright question"|date=1896|publisher=Canada Dept of Agriculture|url=https://archive.org/stream/conferenceoncopy00cana/conferenceoncopy00cana_djvu.txt|language=en}}</ref> The Canadian authorities and publishers were satisfied with the proposal put forward from England as were the American authors and publishers.<ref>{{cite news|title= Mr Hall Caine and the Copyright Question|work= Birmingham Daily Post|date=12 December 1895|page=5}}</ref> The bill never became law, the 1889 Act was abandoned and a more flexible solution was found by 1900.<ref>{{Harvnb|Alexander|2010|p=252.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Lamonde|2005|p=156.}}</ref>
==Peak years== ===Second visit to the United States=== [[File:Portrait of Viola Allen.jpg|thumb|right|<center>''Viola Allen as Glory Quayle''<br>This portrait shows [[Viola Allen]] as she would have appeared in the prologue of ''The Christian'']] Taking two years to write, Caine's novel ''The Christian'' was published by Heinemann in 1897. It is the first novel in Britain to have sold over a million copies<ref name="dnb">{{Citation | last = Allen| first = Vivien| title = Caine, Sir (Thomas Henry) Hall (1853–1931)| work = [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] | publisher = Oxford University Press | origyear = 2004| year = 2011| url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/32237| accessdate = 3 August 2013 }} ({{ODNBsub}})</ref> The book was inspired by Rossetti's verses ''Mary Magdalene At The Door Of Simon The Pharisee'', written for his painting, depicting a man trying to pluck back a woman about to enter the gates of heaven. Caine followed it with a lecture tour of Scotland, a one-man dramatic performance of his novelette ''Home Sweet Home''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=250–251.}}</ref> ''The Christian'' was serialised in Britain in the ''[[Windsor Magazine]]'' between December 1896 and November 1897 and in the United States in ''[[Munsey's Magazine]]'' between November 1896 and January 1898. Mainly set in Victorian London, it is the story of Glory Quayle, a young woman living an independent life who becomes an actress, and John Storm, who enters the priesthood. It was the first time that Caine had taken up [[the Woman Question]]. The character of John Storm is drawn from a composite of the Hon. and Rev. James Adderley, an Anglican priest of Berkley Chapel, Mayfair, London, and [[George Stanton|Father Stanton]], who became an Anglican bishop.<ref>{{Harvnb| Adderley |1916|pp=176–177.}}</ref> Caine dramatised the book in 1896. His play was so popular with the public that the [[Daily Mail]] published it in a thick-paper, illustrated edition.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nichol|2009|p=190.}}</ref> He directed the play, travelling to New York where he went on to deliver a series of lectures and readings there.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=71.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hall Caine and His Son|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Morning%20Telegraph/New%20York%20NY%20Morning%20Telegraph%201898/New%20York%20NY%20Morning%20Telegraph%201898%20-%200185.pdf|accessdate=3 April 2017|work=The Sunday Telegraph|date=18 September 1898|location=New York|page=1}}</ref> [[Viola Allen]] produced the play for the first time on the stage at [[Albany, New York]] on 25 September 1898. It opened at the [[Knickerbocker Theatre (Broadway)|Knickerbocker Theatre]] on 10 October 1898, running for twenty-one weeks in New York. Almost one thousand clergymen attended a matinee on 15 November 1898.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Christian,|work= Indianapolis News |date=8 March 1900}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb| Peteri |2003|pp=103–105.}}</ref> George C. Tyler, reportedly made one million dollars from the Broadway production of ''The Christian''.<ref>{{Harvnb| Rogal |1997|p=286.}}</ref> On his return to London after being on tour, Wilson Barratt gave Caine half of an advance payment received from an Australian manager for Barratt's stage adaptation of ''The Christian''. Caine rejected both the money and the play. Barratt unsuccessfully sued Caine on the grounds that they had an agreement to collaborate on the dramatisation.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=72.}}</ref> ''The Christian'' was first produced in England at the [[Duke of York's Theatre]] in October 1899.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=269.}}</ref> It failed after two months. Caine authorised a touring production with his sister Lily playing Glory Quayle and managed by her husband George Day which in 1907 was still continuously performed by up to three companies.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=73.}}</ref> After Finnish politician and writer [[Aino Malmberg]] sought aid from Caine on her country's behalf, he offered the Finnish rights to the [[Finnish National Theatre]]. Finland belonged to the Russian Empire and was actively seeking Independence. Malmberg translated Caine's works into Finnish.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=269.}}</ref>
===Rome=== Caine and his wife, Mary, spent four winters in Rome, renting a house, 18 Trinità de' Monti, near the [[Spanish Steps]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Hall Caine in New York|work=Chicago Tribune|date=19 October 1902|pages=1}}</ref> On their visit between January and April 1901 Caine finished ''The Eternal City'', his greatest commercial success.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=82.}}</ref> It is Caine's only novel to be first conceived as a play.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=271.}}</ref> The story begins in Rome in 1900 at the fictional Pope Pius X's [[Jubilee (Christianity)|jubilee celebrations]], at the height of the dispute between the [[Vatican City|Vatican]] and the Italian state on the [[Temporal power (papal)|temporal power]] of the Church. David Rossi, a socialist and republican is accused of conspiring to assassinate the Italian king. He opposes Baron Bonelli, a corrupt prime minister. Bonelli tries to prevent the culmination of the love story between his mistress Donna Roma Volonna and Rossi. ''The Eternal City'' was serialised in Britain in 1901 in [[The Lady's Magazine]] and in the United States in [[Collier's Weekly]], between February and August 1901. Immediately afterwards it was published in book form by Heinemann, with an initial print run of 100,000, running to twenty-six editions, selling more than a million copies in English alone and translated into thirteen languages.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=228.}}</ref> The stage adaptation opened at [[Her Majesty's Theatre|His Majesty's Theatre]], London on 2 October 1902, produced by actor-manager [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]], with [[incidental music]] by Italian composer [[Pietro Mascagni]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|pp=78–80.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Mallach|2002|pp=151–152.}}</ref> A week after the play opened in London, Caine republished the novel, cutting all the political parts and following the story of the play making it into a ‘theatre edition’.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=83.}}</ref> The American production of ''The Eternal City'' premiered on 17 November, at the Victoria Theatre, New York City, with [[Viola Allen]] as Roma, [[Frederic De Belleville]] as Bonelli, and Edward J. Morgan as Rossi. Caine supervised rehearsals.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=84.}}</ref> Towards the end of 1903 six companies were performing ''The Eternal City'', in England, USA, Australia and South Africa.
===''Household Words''=== In 1901 Caine bought ''[[Household Words]]'', the literary magazine founded by [[Charles Dickens]] in 1850. He appointed his son Ralph as editor, and it was sold in 1904.<ref>{{cite news|title=- |work=London Daily News|date=20 July 1904|pages=34}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Mr. Ralph Hall the Youngest Editor in London|work=Dundee Evening Post|date=11 December 1901|pages=6}}</ref> ''The Eternal City'' appeared as two instalments in the Christmas 1901 and January 1902 editions.<ref>{{cite news|title=Publications|work=Sheffield Daily Telegraph|date=11 December 1901|pages=3}}</ref> He made many contributions including articles about [[Pope Leo XIII]], whom he had a private audience with, the story ''A Maid of Mona'' and a serialisation of ''The Manxman''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mr Hall Caine on the Pope|work=Bolton Evening News|date=28 November 1901|pages=5}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Will Appear in this day's Household Words|work=London Daily News|date=2 July 1903|pages=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Public Notices|work=Thanet Advertiser|date=7 February 1903|pages=5}}</ref> His writings on Roman Catholicism caused serious offence to his fellow members of the National Club of London, founded as a [[Protestantism|Protestant]] club.<ref>{{cite news|title=Our London Letter|work=Aberdeen Press and Journal|date=4 December 1901|pages=5}}</ref> [[File:Hall Caine by George Wylie Hutchinson.png|thumb|''Hall Caine'' by [[George Wylie Hutchinson]]]]
===Second visit to Iceland=== To obtain local colour for his novel ''[[The Prodigal Son (Hall Caine novel)|The Prodigal Son]]'' Caine visited Iceland in 1903. On one of two exploration trips that started from Reykjavik Caine discovered a cave about 200 feet long in the valley of [[Thingvellir]], afterwards named "Hall's Hellin" (Hall's cave).<ref>{{cite news|title=Mr Hall Caine's Iceland Explorations|work=St James' Gazette|date=2 October 1903|page=7}}</ref> On 26 August Caine was at the close of the Iceland [[Althing]] where he was a guest of Magnús Stephensen, the island's Governor.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mr. Hall Caine in Iceland|work=Gloucestershire Echo|date=7 September 1903|page=1}}</ref> At the Parliamentary dinner which followed, Caine was introduced "as a distinguished "skald" (bard), whose writings were widely known and greatly admired in Iceland".<ref>{{cite news|title=Mr. Hall Caine in Iceland|work=The Advertiser|location=Adelaide|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/5007566|date=9 October 1903|page=4 }}</ref> ''The Prodigal Son'' was published in November 1904 by Heinemann and translated into thirteen languages. It is set in a sheep-rearing community in rural Iceland, with scenes in London and the [[French Riviera]]. In ''The Prodigal Son'' Magnus learns on his wedding day that his bride, Thora, is in love with his brother Oscar, a composer. She marries Oscar after Magnus releases her from the engagement. When Thora dies, a distraught Oscar places the only copies of his compositions in her coffin. Later he has her grave opened and his music retrieved. Caine's use of a similar event to Rossetti's exhumation of Elizabeth Siddal, where Rossetti recovered his poems that he had buried with her, caused a lasting rift between Caine and the Rossetti family.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=90.}}</ref> ''The Prodigal Son'' was simultaneously dramatised, the copyright performance held at the Grand Theatre, [[Douglas, Isle of Man|Douglas]]. American and British productions opened days apart in 1905, at the [[National Theatre (Washington, D.C.)|National Theatre in Washington, D. C.]] on 28 August, the [[New Amsterdam Theatre]] in New York City on 4 September and at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]], London on 7 September, with [[George Alexander (actor)|George Alexander]] playing Oscar and Caine's sister Lilian playing Thora.<ref>{{cite news|title=Heard in the Green-Room|work=The Sketch|date=6 September 1905|page=37}}</ref> After a long run at Drury Lane it was revived in 1907.<ref>{{Harvnb|Barker|1999|p=28.}}</ref>
In September 1906 Caine's dramatised version of ''The Bondman'' was produced in London's [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]], with [[Mrs Patrick Campbell]] playing a leading role and Caine's son, Derwent (aged sixteen), making a stage début.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=315.}}</ref> A copyright performance had taken place at the Theatre Royal, Bolton in November 1982.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=199.}}</ref> Caine revised the play for [[Arthur Collins (theatre manager)|Arthur Collins]], moving part of the story to [[Sicily]] and creating a happy ending.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=92.}}</ref> The highlight of the show was the sulphur mine explosion and volcano eruption. In April 1906 Collins and Caine had gone on a research trip where they spent a day with Leone Testa, the inspector-general of Sicily's sulphur mines and while visiting [[Naples]] they witnessed [[Mount Vesuvius]] erupt. The show ran for eleven weeks followed by eight weeks at the [[Adelphi Theatre]] and a revival of The Prodigal Son. The production went on tour in the UK and America.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=95.}}</ref> Japanese actor and a founder of Japanese modern theatre [[Otojirō Kawakami]] staged the play in Japan in 1909, changing the setting to Japan and the Philippines and included the volcanic eruption. When Kawakami’s new western style theatre Teikoku-za opened in Osaka in March 1910 the first production was The Bondman.
1908 saw the publication of ''My Story'', described by Bram Stoker as "autobiographical rather than an autobiography and gives insight to the life and character of his many friends and their influence on his life and work, and of the gradual growth of his mind and of his importance in the world as the success of each book gave him further opportunities."<ref>{{cite news|first=Bram|last=Stoker|title=The Ethics of Hall Caine|work= The Homiletic Review| date=August 1909|page=98|url=http://www.bramstoker.org/pdf/nonfic/ethics.pdf|access-date=3 March 2017}}</ref>
===Egyptian nationalism=== On 13 June 1906 British officers shot pigeons for sport in Denshawai, an Egyptian village whose inhabitants were pigeon farmers, resulting in a clash between the officers and several villagers. One villager, falsely accused of murder was killed on the spot. Four villagers were hanged and others punished by jail sentences, hard labour and lashings. The [[Denshawai Incident]] proved a turning point in the history of the British occupation of Egypt, starting a fierce political debate both in Eygpt and Britain in which intellectuals and men of letters participated, eventually causing the resignation of [[Evelyn Baring, 1st Earl of Cromer|Lord Cromer]], the redoubtable British Consul General and de facto ruler of Egypt since 1882. Crucially poet [[Wilfred Scawen Blunt]] exposed the facts in his pamphlet ''Atrocities of Justice Under British Rule in Egypt'', provoking a public outcry in Britain. [[George Bernard Shaw]] drafted a petition published in ''The New Age'' with the main purpose of gaining the release of the Egyptian prisoners.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Denshawai Prisoners|url=http://wallace-online.org/content/frameset?keywords=denshawai&pageseq=1&itemID=S646a&viewtype=text|accessdate=28 April 2017|website=wallace-online.org|language=en}}</ref> Shaw denounces the "Denshawai horror" in his ''Preface to Politicians'' that introduces his ''John Bull's Other Island''. Caine's literary response to the debate is his controversial novel ''The White Prophet.''<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=318,339.}}</ref> Shaw reviews ''The White Prophet'' and opposes literary censorship in ''Bernard Shaw on Shams of Rule and of Religion''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Shaw|1996|pp=230–240.}}</ref> Set in Egypt at the start of the twentieth century, twenty years into the British occupation and opening with a ceremonial re-enactment of the [[Battle of Omdurman]], ''The White Prophet'' is the story of Colonel Charles George Lord, a British officer who joins the crusade of Ishmael Ameer, a Muslim prophet against selfishness and sedition. Lord compares him with Christ and John the Baptist. Ameer plans a coup against the British in Sudan, after developing political ambitions. ''The White Prophet'' is Caine's only book never to have been reprinted; its sympathies for [[Egyptian nationalism]] rendered it a commercial failure.<ref>{{Harvnb|Diamond|2006|p=65.}}</ref> Caine used material from ''Mahomet'' and ''The Mahdi'' in the novel. Accompanied by his wife, he made three research visits to Egypt, March to May 1907, then January to May in 1908 and similarly in 1909 when he was joined by actor manager [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Connor|2007|p=207.}}</ref> Cromer failed to meet Caine during his visit to Egypt in 1907, instead Caine wrote urging him to grant the Egyptians wish "for a speedy fulfilment of England's promise to get out of Egypt as soon as it was safe to do so" and to "yield to legitimate claims to national independence".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=319.}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=211.}}</ref> Originally entitled ''The White Christ'', it was serialised in the British and US editions of ''The Strand Magazine'' between December 1908 and November 1909, and subsequently translated into seven languages. The Arabic translation was serialised in Cairo-based newspaper ''al-Minbar''.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=215.}}</ref> [[Douglas Sladen]] read the first two instalments of ''The White Prophet'' and had the idea of writing a counterblast, the novel ''The Tragedy of the Pyramids: A Romance of Army Life in Egypt''. Closing the preface he writes "I felt bound to challenge the false light in which he presents the British Army of Occupation in Egypt to the public".<ref>{{Harvnb|Sladen|1909|pp=xi-xxiii.}}</ref> A copyright performance was performed at the [[Garrick Theatre]], London on 27 November 1908. Beerbohm Tree's plans to produce a dramatised version at [[His Majesty's Theatre, London]], which he was to direct and star in, were abandoned following threats to lobby the Lord Chamberlain against granting a license for the play, banning it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Shaw on Caine's Work|work=Sacramento Union|location= California US|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SU19091115.2.125|date=15 November 1909}}</ref> Cromer is reported to have protested to the Lord Chamberlain's Department that "the state of the Nationalist agitation in Egypt made a dramatic representation of some of its features injudicious".<ref>{{cite news|title=A Hall Caine Play Banned|work= Dundee Evening Telegraph |date=2 June 1909}}</ref> The character of John Lord is widely believed to be Cromer.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=220.}}</ref> Promoting the publication of ''The White Prophet'' by Heinemann on 12 August 1909, Caine published a series of eight articles ''Aspects of the East'' in ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Heinemann published Shaw's ''The Critics of The White Prophet'' as a pamphlet, endorsing the novel's political viewpoint. It was to have been the preface for the second edition.<ref>{{Harvnb|Waller|2008|pp=737–738.}}</ref>
On 15 August 1910, Caine's new stage adaptation of ''The Deemster'' entitled ''The Bishop's Son'' opened at the Grand Theatre, [[Douglas, Isle of Man]], with Caine's son, Derwent, playing Dan. It went on to open at London's [[Garrick Theatre]] on 28 September 1910 with [[Bransby Williams]] as Dan, which ran for seven performances.
===Controversy of ''The Woman Thou Gavest Me''=== Caine's novel ''The Woman Thou Gavest Me: Being the Story of Mary O'Neill'', published by Heinemann in 1913, "caused the biggest furore of any of his novels".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=351.}}</ref> Translated into nine languages, worldwide advance orders for the book exceeded 200,000.<ref>{{Harvnb|Tetens|2015|p=6.}}</ref> From October 1912 it was serialised in Britain in ''Nash's Magazine'' and concurrently in the United States in ''[[Hearst's Magazine]]''. The following month serialisation began in ''[[The Australian Women's Weekly]]''. [[Circulating libraries]] divided new books into three categories: satisfactory, doubtful and objectionable.<ref>{{Harvnb|Hammond|2006|p=28.}}</ref> They attempted to boycott ''The Woman Thou Gavest Me'' along with [[Compton Mackenzie]]'s ''Sinister Street'' and [[W. B. Maxwell]]'s ''The Devil's Garden'', for failing their criteria. The authors directed a publicity campaign opposing the boycott.<ref>{{Harvnb|Bradshaw|2013|p=66.}}</ref> ''The Woman Thou Gavest Me'', the second of Caine's novels to address the Woman Question, "arraigns the divorce laws" of the time.<ref>{{cite news|title=A Book Boycotted|work= Otago Daily Times|location= New Zealand|url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT19130802.2.58|date=2 August 1913}}</ref> Father [[Bernard Vaughan]], known for his sermons on ''The Sins of Society'', denounced Caine's book saying "it showed startling ignorance of Roman Catholic doctrine and practice".<ref>{{cite news|title=A Novel Denounced|work=Waikato Argus|location= New Zealand|url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WAIGUS19131001.2.25.|date=1 October 1913}}</ref> The novel was one of several books the Catholic Federation in [[Auckland]], New Zealand wanted removed from sale.<ref>{{cite news|title=A Priest and a Book.|work=Sun|location= New Zealand|url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/SUNCH19140519.2.13|date=19 May 1914}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=A Novel Denounced|work=The Monitor And New Era|location=London|url= https://newspaperarchive.com/london-monitor-and-new-era-oct-04-1913-p-6/ |page=6|date=4 October 1913}}</ref> In [[Wyndham, Western Australia]] the committee of Little River Mechanics Institute Free Library ordered the book banned and burnt.<ref>{{cite news|title=Public listing status for the Little River Mechanics Institute Free Library|work=Wyndham Leader|location= Western Australia US|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/leader/news/public-listing-status-for-the-little-river-mechanics-institute-free-library/news-story/b1219e39ef5294b69fb1bfe5084f8e14|date=25 July 2015}}</ref> American newspapers reported of a [[Methodism|Methodist]] preacher's daughter that eloped and married the son of a prominent family, who later divorced her and took away her child. She was arrested on the street for Immorality. After three days in jail [[Eugene V. Debs]], five times Socialist candidate for [[President of the United States]] sheltered her in his home. It was Debs’ "challenge to the Christianity of [[Terre Haute]]", Indiana. Parallels were drawn between the problem that Debs handled in real life and Caine's fictional story of Mary O'Neill, who marries unhappily and ends up on the street without shelter, with the whole world turned against her.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Woman That Debs Took Into His House—And Hall Caine's Extraordinary Novel, "The Woman Thou Gavest Me" Deb* Has Made an Interesting Experiment. It Is a Lesson and Rebuke by the Socialist Candidate for President |work=Los Angeles Herald|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=LAH19130718.2.51|date=18 July 1913}}</ref> ''The Woman Thou Gavest Me'' was reprinted five times before the end of 1913 when nearly half a million copies had been sold.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=351.}}</ref> [[The Times Literary Supplement]] listed it as the most popular novel of that year. New York's [[The Bookman (New York)|Bookman]], listed it as the fifth best-seller of October 1913.<ref>{{cite news|title=Best Books of the Year|work=Evening Star|location=New Zealand|url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ESD19131227.2.120| page=11|date=27 December 1913}}</ref>
English fiction was represented in Europe by Hall Caine, as French fiction was by [[Anatole France]], Italian by [[Gabriele D'Annunzio]], and German by [[Hermann Sudermann]].<ref>{{cite news|title=A Much Criticised Novel|work=Manawatu Times|location= New Zealand|url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/MT19130924.2.58|date=24 September 1913}}</ref> "Among English novelists who have made from fifty to sixty cents for every word in a long novel are Hall Caine and [[Marie Corelli]]. Compared with such money earners as these, [[Charles Dickens|Dickens]], [[William Makepeace Thackeray|Thackeray]], and [[George Eliot]] were poorly paid for their labor".<ref>{{cite journal|title=Authors Who Get $1.00 a Word|journal=The Journal of Education|date=1 January 1907|volume=66|issue=20 (1655)|page=550|jstor=42816292}}</ref>
==Politics== On 24 October 1901 Caine was elected a [[Member of the House of Keys]] in a by-election as a [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] for the constituency of [[Ramsey, Isle of Man]], by a majority of 267 votes. Caine sought election to the Keys after the collapse of {{Proper name|Dumbell}}'s Banking Company on 3 February 1901.<ref>{{Harvnb|Norris|1947|p=36.}}</ref> The crash had resulted in a number of resignations and retirements, resulting in eleven by-elections.<ref>{{Harvnb| Kermode |2001|p=26.}}</ref> The Bank had held most of the island's cash deposits and left businesses and residents without money.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Manx Sun History of Dumbell's Bank|year=1900|url=http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/fulltext/ms1900/p001.htm}}</ref> At the General election in 1903 Caine was re-elected for another five years.
During Caine's election campaign he supported dominion status for the Island with a Manxman as Lieutenant-Governor, a directly elected [[Legislative Council of the Isle of Man|Legislative Council]] and departmental officials appointed by and responsible to [[Tynwald]]. A pamphlet entitled ''Hall Caine's Letters and Speeches on Manx Politics'' was published in 1903, containing his election speech and articles he wrote for the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' and ''[[Black and White (magazine)|Black and White]]'', describing his experiences and aspirations. In recognition of his single election speech Caine was appointed vice-president of the Land Nationalisation Society of Great Britain.<ref>{{Harvnb|Norris|1947|p=42.}}</ref>
The Manx National Reform League made constitutional and social reform the central issues in the general election of 1903, after an extra-parliamentary initiative by journalist and printer Samuel Norris. It was influenced by Liberal demands for political change in the United Kingdom. In 1903 Caine was elected the first president of the Manx National Reform League. In 1904 the new House of Keys established a committee on constitutional reform, chaired by Caine, that prepared the 1907 petition for constitutional reform.<ref>{{Harvnb| Kermode|2001|pp39=42.}}</ref>
Caine retired from active politics in 1908. Due to the other pressures on his time he seldom spoke in the Keys. He also had little time to offer to politics on a larger scale. Prior to the Ramsey by-election, Caine was invited by [[David Lloyd George|Lloyd George]] to stand for the [[British parliament]] but he refused.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=282–284.}}</ref>
==The Great War==
Caine was aged 61 at the outbreak of the Great War. The British secretly set up the War Propaganda Bureau under MP [[Charles Masterman]]. Caine was one of twenty-five leading authors Masterman invited to the Bureau's London headquarters, [[Wellington House]] on 2 September 1914 with the purpose of best [[British propaganda during World War I|promoting Britain's interests during the war]].<ref>{{Harvnb| Buitenhuis |2011|p=14.}}</ref> Shortly after, Caine was one of fifty-three of the leading authors in Britain to sign the 'Authors' Declaration', a manifesto drafted by Masterman stating that Britain "could not without dishonour have refused to take part in the present war." Issued on 17 September the document was sent by special cable to the ''New York Times''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pen and Sword Pt. I: The Authors’ Declaration {{!}} World War I Centenary|url=http://ww1centenary.oucs.ox.ac.uk/unconventionalsoldiers/propaganda-the-authors-declaration/|website=ww1centenary.oucs.ox.ac.uk|accessdate=2 June 2017}}</ref> Caine abandoned literary contracts in America valued at 150,000 dollars in order to devote all his energies to the British war effort.<ref>{{Harvnb|Norris|1947|p=62.}}</ref> [[File:Caine war book.jpg|thumb|left|The cover of ''The Drama of 365 Days: Scenes in the Great War'', Caine's series of ''Daily Telegraph'' World War I propaganda articles. The book is dedicated to the young manhood of the British Empire.]] Following the [[Rape of Belgium]] Caine edited ''King Albert's Book'' in support of the exiled [[Albert I of Belgium|King Albert of Belgium]].<ref>Caine, Hall (ed.), ''King Albert's Book, a Tribute to the Belgian King and People from representative men and women throughout the World'' (The Daily Telegraph, in conjunction with The Daily Sketch, The Glasgow Herald and Hodder & Stoughton, Christmas 1914) ''"Sold in aid of the Daily Telegraph Belgian Fund."''</ref> It was Caine's idea and was published at Christmas 1914 by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. The proceeds from the book, £20,000, went to the Daily Telegraph Belgium Fund, a fund created to support British efforts to receive and maintain Belgian refugees in Britain. In previous years Caine had edited several of these volumes already, the most recent for Queen Alexandra's charities in 1905 and 1908. Caine invited authors, artists, composers, statesmen and many notable people to present their view of events in Belgium. ''King Albert‘s Book'' contains contributions from two hundred and fifty of the most famous people of the time. Among the contributors are British [[Prime Minister Asquith]] and then Lord of the Admiralty [[Winston Churchill]], painters [[Claude Monet]] and [[John Collier (painter)|John Collier]] and composer [[Claude Debussy]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Britain's homage to 'plucky Belgium'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/history/world-war-one/11295047/Britains-homage-to-plucky-Belgium.html|website=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=29 May 2017|language=en}}</ref>
King Albert of Belgium made Caine an Officer of the [[Order of Leopold II|Order of Leopold of Belgium]] for his humanitarian aid to the Belgian refugees in 1918. Caine's portrait by the Belgian painter, [[Alfred Jonniaux]], was presented to him by the Fine Art Department of the Belgian Government.<ref>{{cite news|title=Books of the Day|work=Illustrated London News|date=6 August 1921|page=8}}</ref><ref name=Jonniaux group=nb/>
Caine wrote extensively in the English, American and Italian newspapers. He claimed that by this work and his personal influence with Italian statesmen he greatly helped bring Italy into the war on the side of the allies.<ref>{{Harvnb|Norris|1947|p=62.}}</ref> President [[Woodrow Wilson]] had declared the United States neutral and his policy of neutrality was enormously popular with the American people.<ref>{{cite web|title=President Wilson's Declaration of Neutrality – World War I Document Archive|url=https://wwi.lib.byu.edu/index.php/President_Wilson's_Declaration_of_Neutrality|website=wwi.lib.byu.edu|accessdate=3 June 2017|language=en}}</ref> Caine urged America to join the war by writing articles, mainly for ''[[The New York Times]]'' and in 1915 he gave a series of lectures in the United States but these were not well received. In September 1915, at the conclusion of the first year of war, a series of articles featuring royalty, countries and events which included [[Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria|Archduke Ferdinand]], the [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Kaiser]] and the [[Sinking of the RMS Lusitania]] that Caine had contributed to ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' were published as a book entitled ''The Drama of 365 Days: Scenes in the Great War''. Caine attended Nurse [[Edith Cavell]]'s memorial service in [[St Paul's Cathedral]], London, on 29 October 1915; the World War I British nurse who is celebrated for saving the lives of soldiers in Brussels from all sides without distinction.
