His account was published in The Daily Telegraph on 30 October and extensively in other newspapers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Daily Telegraph October 30 1915|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/ww1-archive/11961168/Daily-Telegraph-October-30-1915.html|website=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=3 June 2017|language=en}}</ref> In 1916 he was invited to work with [[Robert Cecil, 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood|Lord Robert Cecil]] at the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office|Foreign Office]] towards the creation of the [[League of Nations]] after the end of the war. ''Our Girls: Their Work for the War'', is the title of Caine's Christmas book published by [[Hutchinson (publisher)|Messrs Hutchinson]] early in December 1916, consisting of a series of Caine's articles written for the [[Ministry of Munitions]], together with additional stories of women's working lives in the factories and in the hospitals. It was designed to be a gift for [[Munitionettes|munitions girls]] to send to their men at the front.
The National War Aims Committee was set up in 1917 to focus on domestic propaganda. Caine was recruited for the committee by the Prime Minister [[David Lloyd George]] to write the screenplay for the [[World War I film propaganda|propaganda]] film ''[[Victory and Peace]]'', designed to show what would happen in a German invasion.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hall Caine's Task|work=Shields Daily News|date=10 November 1917|pages=4}}</ref> Most of the negative of the newly finished film was destroyed in a fire at the offices of the London Film Company in June 1918.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sir Hall Caine's propaganda film destroyed|work=Aberdeen Press and Journal|date=19 June 1918|pages=4}}</ref> It was re-filmed over four-months, just as the war ended and was never released.<ref>{{Harvnb|Slide |2015|Chapter=11.}}</ref>
Towards the end of 1917 Caine was offered a [[baron]]etcy in recognition of the contribution he made to the war effort as an allied propagandist and his position as a leading [[intellectual|man of letters]]. Caine declined the hereditary peerage and accepted a [[knight]]hood instead. He was made [[Order of the British Empire|Knight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire(KBE)]], insisting on being called, not 'Sir Thomas' but 'Sir Hall'.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=367–368.}}</ref>
==After the war==
Caine returned to writing novels and in 1921 Heinmann's published '' [[The Master of Man|The Master of Man: The Story of a Sin]]''. It was set in the Isle of Man and involves [[infanticide]]. Initially it sold well but sales soon dropped. It was considered to be old-fashioned; Caine was using old themes and had not kept up with the time. One reviewer referred to Caine as "this Victorian author".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=380–381.}}</ref> The following year Caine acquired the ''Sunday Illustrated'' newspaper which had been founded by [[Horatio Bottomley]]. In October of that year he was made a [[Order of the Companions of Honour|Companion of Honour]]. Caine's last novel ''[[The Woman of Knockaloe]]'' was brought out in 1923, this time published by [[Cassell (publisher)|Cassell's]]. It is another love story set on the Isle of Man but this time dealing with the harm caused by racial hatred. That year he sold the ''Sunday Illustrated''. On Armistice Day 1923 Caine's first radio broadcast, ''A Counsel of Peace'', was made to the nation from the [[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]] in London.<ref>{{cite news|title=The World's Remedy.|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/106739363|work=Daily Herald|location=Adelaide|accessdate=2 November 2017|date=8 January 1924|pages=4}}Full text of ''A Counsel of Peace''</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sir Hall Caine|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/56bbef3d1c33498eb7287f157b95396f|website=The Radio Times|accessdate=2 November 2017|pages=2, 7|date=9 November 1923}}</ref>
Caine's last published work in his lifetime was a revised version of ''Recollections of Rossetti'', with a shortened title, to coincide with the 1928 centenary of Rossetti's birth. In 1929 Caine was given the [[Freedom of the City|Freedom]] of Douglas. For much of his life Caine worked on a book entitled ''Life of Christ'' but it was not published until some time after his death, in 1938 with a foreword by his two sons. It "aroused little or no interest and quickly disappeared".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=430.}}</ref>
==Films== [[File:Hall Caine Visits the Set of “The Christian,” 1922.jpg|thumb|Hall Caine's visit to ''The Christian'' film set in 1922, Left to right: Caine, [[Mae Busch]] (Glory Quayle), [[Maurice Tourneur]] (Director), and [[Richard Dix]](John Storm).]] Most of Caine's novels were made into [[black-and-white]] [[silent film|silent]] films. The first film made was [[The Christian (1911 film)|''The Christian'' (1911)]], by [[West's Pictures]] in Australia. The twenty-eight minute unauthorised film was the first directed by [[Franklyn Barrett]]. ''The Christian'' features the cast of the stage production by [[William Anderson (theatre)|William Anderson]]'s Company. An unauthorised film of ''[[The Bondman (1916 film)|The Bondman'' (1916)]] was made by [[Fox Film Corporation]] in the United States and was the first film they released under their De Luxe brand. All of Fox's 110 musicians accompanied ''The Bondman'' screenings. The music was composed by [[Max Steiner]], Fox's musical director. A financial and critical success it was re-released in 1918 as one of Fox's Big Six.
The first authorised film of a Caine novel is ''[[The Christian (1914 film)|The Christian]]'' (1914) released in the United States by the [[Vitagraph|Vitagraph Liebler Company]]. The first eight reel film they made. Vitagraph leased the Harris Theatre on West 42nd Street, for the purpose of exclusively showing their own films, opening with ''The Christian'' starring [[Earle Williams]] and [[Edith Storey]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Vitagraph article|url=http://www.silentsaregolden.com/articles/vitagrapharticle.html|website=www.silentsaregolden.com}}</ref> Caine wrote the film scenario, the first time ever that a famous author undertook a film scenario of their own work. Vitagraph staff writer Eugene Mullins followed Caine’s own scenario.<ref>{{cite web|title=The sun. (New York [N.Y.]) 1833-1916, February 15, 1914, FOURTH SECTION PICTORIAL MAGAZINE, Image 36|url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1914-02-15/ed-1/seq-36/#|date=15 February 1914}}</ref>
Adapted and directed by established American screenwriter and director [[George Loane Tucker]], ''[[The Christian (1915 film)|The Christian]]'' (1915) was made by the London Film Company. The 9,000 feet film starred Caine's son [[Derwent Hall Caine]] as John Storm. ''[[The Manxman (1916 film)|The Manxman]]'' (1916), also produced by the London Film Company and directed by Tucker, was filmed on the Isle of Man and, when released drew huge crowds in Britain and America. It was one of the few British films distributed in the United States that went on to become a financial and critical success.<ref>{{cite journal|last=[[National Board of Review]]|year=1951|title=Book Reviews|journal=Films in Review|publisher=National Board of Review of Motion Pictures|volume=2|page=55|issn=0015-1688}}</ref> Starring Derwent Hall Caine and [[Marian Swayne]] ''The Deemster'' (1917), made in the United States, is the first special feature film Arrow Film Corporation made. Shot on location on [[Block Island|Block Island, Rhode Island]], the film was originally entitled ''The Bishop’s Son'' after Caine’s 1910 stage adaptation of ''The Deemster'' in which Derwent had also played Dan Mylrea and on which the film is based. Caine remained closely involved with the production; based in England, Caine reviewed the scenario and produced drawings of the character of the buildings to be used. ''[[The Christian (1923 film)|The Christian]]'' was also remade in 1923, produced by [[Samuel Goldwyn]], and directed by the celebrated [[Maurice Tourneur]].
[[Adolph Zukor]]’s Famous Players Film Company produced the first version of ''[[The Eternal City (1915 film)|The Eternal City (1915)]]''. The $100,000 epic film featured stage star [[Pauline Frederick]]. Made on location in London and Italy in 1914 the production was interrupted by the start of the [[Great War]] and was completed in New York. For distribution of initially ''The Eternal City'' and other prestigious feature-length films Famous Players created the Select Booking Agency. Caine cabled the producers after attending the British premiere at Marble Arch Pavilion, in London congratulating them.<ref>{{cite news |title=England Likes "Eternal City" |url=https://archive.org/stream/clipper63-1915-10#page/n65/ |work=New York Clipper |publisher=New York, NY: Frank Queen Publishing Co. |date=9 October 1915 |page=18}}</ref> The film was re-released in 1918 as part of the Paramount "Success Series". In 1923 the Samuel Goldwyn Company shot a [[The Eternal City (1923 film)|remake]] in Italy. Caine was so unhappy with the latter film that he tried to withdraw his name from it, unsuccessfully.<ref>{{Harvnb|Brownlow|1990|p=457.}}</ref>
Prime Minister [[David Lloyd George]] recruited Caine in 1917 to write the screenplay for the propaganda film ''[[Victory and Peace]]'' (1918), made in Britain and directed by [[Herbert Brenon]]. Caine was appointed as chief adviser to the film campaign department of the National War Aims Committee. Lloyd George chose Caine due to his experience in the field of cinema and his "reputation as a man of letters".<ref>{{cite news|title=Letter from Lloyd George to Hall Caine, dated 23 October 1917, reprinted in the Daily Telegraph|work=Daily Telegraph|date=10 November 1917}}</ref> On 20 September 1917, in [[Ithaca, New York]], Brenon’s representative obtained the film rights of ''The Woman Thou Gavest Me'' from [[Derwent Hall Caine]], Caine’s American agent, intending to start work in November 1917. The film was advertised but it was never made by Brenon. A film of ''[[The Woman Thou Gavest Me]]'' was made in 1919 by Famous Players and this drew good audiences and good reviews.
Caine wrote the screenplay of ''[[Darby and Joan (1920 film)|Darby and Joan]]''. Made by Master Films the 1920 film is directed by [[Percy Nash]] featuring [[Derwent Hall Caine]] and [[Ivy Close]]. Many of the scenes were shot in the Isle of Man.<ref>{{cite news|title=Globe|date=7 January 1918|page=3}}</ref> ''The Woman of Knockaloe'' was filmed by [[Paramount Pictures]] in 1927 as ''[[Barbed Wire (1927 film)|Barbed Wire]]''. Then [[Alfred Hitchcock]] arrived on the Isle of Man to film ''[[The Manxman]]'' (1929) but he and Caine did not get on well and the rest of the film was shot in Cornwall. ''The Manxman'' was Hitchcock's last silent film. Caine was not happy with it.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=416.}}</ref>
After retiring from the army in 1922, Colonel Hanna joined the [[British Board of Film Censors]] and held the position of vice-president and chief censor throughout the 1930s. [[Gaumont British]]'s plan to film ''The White Prophet'' was abandoned after objections by Colonel Hanna as he thought it contained scenes with "a tendency to bring the British army into contempt and ridicule" and that "no scene of cavalry charging the mob and causing 100 deaths….would be permissible on the screen".<ref>{{Harvnb|Richards|2009|p=146.}}</ref>
Shortly before Caine's death in 1931, [[Metro Goldwyn Mayer]] purchased the screen rights of ''The Christian'' with the intention of making a [[talking picture]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Hall Caine Novel as Talkie|work= Daily Herald|date=1 May 1931|page=8}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hall Caine Film|work=The Derby Daily Telegraph|date=1 May 1931|page=6}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Happenings of the Stage and Screen|work=Pittsburg Post- Gazette|date=13 May 1931|page=10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article83696833 |title=Union Theatre's Scoop |newspaper=[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|Daily News]] |volume=L |issue=17 |location=Western Australia |date=15 December 1931 |accessdate=7 January 2018 |page=6|edition=HOME (FINAL) |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The rights were reported as selling for £8000.
==Personal and domestic== In appearance Caine was a short man who tended to dress in a striking fashion. His eyes were dark brown and slightly protuberant, giving him an intense stare. He had red-gold hair and a dark red beard which he trimmed to appear like the [[Stratford-upon-Avon|Stratford]] [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]] of [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]; indeed if people did not notice the likeness he was inclined to point it out to them.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=35–36.}}</ref> He was also preoccupied throughout his life with the state of his health. This was often the result of overwork or other stresses in his life and he would sometimes use nervous exhaustion as an excuse to escape from his problems.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=24, 213.}}</ref>
[[File:Hall Caine's grave, Maughold, Isle of Man.JPG|thumb|left|Hall Caine's grave, designed by [[Archibald Knox (designer)|Archibald Knox]], [[Maughold (parish)|Maughold]], [[Isle of Man]]]] In 1902 the Caines rented a large house on [[Wimbledon, London|Wimbledon]] Common, The Hermitage, and Mary spent much time there while Caine was abroad or at Greeba Castle. Rumours spread that the marriage was in trouble and, as many of his visitors were male, that Caine was [[Gay|homosexual]]. However, there was never any reliable substance to this.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=292.}}</ref> By 1906 the couple were leading increasingly separate lives but Mary remained loyal and faithful throughout.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=313.}}</ref>
In 1912, Derwent Hall Caine had an illegitimate daughter, Elin, and she was brought up as Caine and Mary's child.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=348–350.}}</ref> By 1914 Mary at last had her own London house – Heath Brow which overlooked [[Hampstead Heath]]. After the Great War this house had become too big and Mary moved into Heath End House, again overlooking Hampstead Heath. By 1922 they informally separated; Caine could not live with Mary, nor could he break with her completely.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=388–389.}}</ref> From that time, both suffered from various ailments.
On 31 August 1931, aged 78 Caine slipped into a coma and died at his home, [[Greeba Castle]], Isle of Man. On his death certificate is the diagnosis of "cardiac syncope".<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=423.}}</ref> Following his death messages of condolence were received from the Prime Minister [[Ramsay MacDonald]], King George V and Queen Mary. <ref>{{cite news|title=King's Condolence With Lady Hall Caine|work=The Nottingham Evening Post|date=1 September 1931|page=5}}</ref>
At Caine's funeral on Friday 4 September 1931 representatives of all branches of public life in the Isle of Man followed the coffin. Sixty thousand Manx people and holiday makers paid tribute on the 25 mile journey. At Douglas great crowds lined the route and the majority of businesses closed. An address was made by the Bishop of Man. Caine was buried in [[Maughold (parish)|Kirk Maughold]] [[churchyard]].<ref>{{cite news|title=60,000 Mourn passing of Sir Hall Caine|work=Daily Herald|date=5 September 1931|page=9}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|title=Funeral of Sir Hall Caine|work=Hull Daily Mail|date=4 September 1931|page=12}}</ref>
A memorial service was held at [[St Martin-in-the-Fields]], London on 9 September 1931. [[Reginald John Campbell|Rev. J. Campbell]] gave the address. The Prime Minister was represented by Charles Patrick Duff, and [[A. J. Sylvester|Albert James Sylvester]] represented [[Lloyd George]]. In March 1932, six months after her husband's death, Mary Hall Caine died from pneumonia. She was buried alongside her husband.
An Irish limestone obelisk depicting six characters from Caine's novels and a likeness of Mary was erected over their grave. The design is based on the ancient Maughold Parish Cross that is preserved in the churchyard.<ref>{{Harvnb|Norris|1947|p=74.}}</ref> The memorial is the work of artist [[Archibald Knox (designer)|Archibald Knox]].
A statue of Hall Caine stands in Douglas, financed by money from the estate of Derwent Hall Caine.
==Postscript==
===Caine's legacy=== Hall Caine was an enormously popular and best-selling author in his time. Crowds would gather outside his houses hoping to get a glimpse of him. He was "accorded the adulation reserved now for pop stars and footballers",<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|p=7.}}</ref> and yet he is now virtually unknown.
Allen suggests two reasons for this. First that, in comparison with Dickens, his characters are not clearly drawn, they are "frequently fuzzy at the edges" while Dickens' characters are "diamond-clear"; and Caine's characters also tend to be much the same as each other. Something similar could also be said about his plots. Possibly the main drawback is that although Caine's books can be romantic and emotionally moving, they lack humour; they are deadly earnest and serious.<ref>{{Harvnb|Allen|1997|pp=430–431.}}</ref>
At one time the Isle of Man had a second civil airport near Ramsey which was called the [[Hall Caine Airport]]. It closed in 1939.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.mers.org.im/hallcaineairport.htm |title=Hall Caine Airport |accessdate=2007-09-02 |work=Mers Online |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121193606/http://www.mers.org.im/hallcaineairport.htm |archivedate=21 November 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Critical appraisals=== * Despite his proving the wealthiest of Victorian novelists,<ref>J. Sutherland, ''The Stanford Companion to Victorian Fiction'' (1990) p. 97-9</ref> Caine has been largely dismissed as a mere [[melodrama]]tist by subsequent criticism.<ref>I. Ousby ed., ''The Cambridge Guide to Literature in English'' (1995) p. 144</ref> * [[G. K. Chesterton]] said in "A Defence of [[Penny Dreadfuls]]" that "it is quite clear that this objection, the objection brought by magistrates, has nothing to do with literary merit. Bad story writing is not a crime. Mr. Hall Caine walks the streets openly, and cannot be put in prison for an anticlimax."<ref>[http://www.cse.dmu.ac.uk/~mward/gkc/books/penny-dreadfuls.html A DEFENCE OF PENNY DREADFULS<!-- bot-generated title -->] at www.cse.dmu.ac.uk</ref> * [[Thomas Hardy]] criticised Caine for his excessive [[egotism]].<ref>M. Seymour-Smith, ''Thomas Hardy'' (1994) p. 645</ref>

{{no footnotes|date=June 2011}} [[Image:Jacques Laurent Agasse 001.jpg|thumb|''[[Playground|The playground]]'' (''Der Spielplatz'')]] [[Image:The nubian giraffe.jpg|thumb|''The Nubian Giraffe'', by Jacques-Laurent Agasse (c.1827), depicts one of the three [[giraffe]]s sent to Europe by [[Mehmet Ali Pasha]] (another was [[Giraffe given to Charles X of France by Muhammad Ali of Egypt|Zarafa]]). This one was received by [[George IV of the United Kingdom|George IV]] in [[London]]. The gentleman shown in the top hat is [[Edward Cross (zoo proprietor)|Edward Cross]], operator of the [[menagerie]] at [[Exeter Exchange]] and then [[Royal Surrey Gardens]]. Agasse painted many other animals from his collection.]]
'''Jacques-Laurent Agasse''' (April 24, 1767 – December 27, 1849) was an [[animal]] and [[Landscape art|landscape]] [[Painting|painter]] from Switzerland.
Born at [[Geneva]], Agasse studied in the public art school of that city. Before he turned twenty he went to [[Paris]] to study in veterinary school to make himself fully acquainted with the anatomy of horses and other animals. He seems to have subsequently returned to [[Switzerland]]. The ''Tübinger Morgenblatt'' (1808, p. 876) says that "Agasse, the celebrated animal [[Painting|painter]], now in [[England]], owed his fortune to an accident. About eight years ago, he being then in [[Switzerland]], a rich Englishman ([[George Pitt, 2nd Baron Rivers|George Pitt]], later Lord Rivers) asked him to paint his favourite dog ([[greyhound]]) which had died. The Englishman was so pleased with his work that he took the painter to [[England]] with him."
Nagler says that he was one of the most celebrated animal painters at the end of the 18th and the beginning of the 19th century. In [[Johann Georg Meusel]]'s ''Neue Miscellaneen'' (viii. 1052 et seq.), he compares Agasse and [[Philips Wouwerman|Wouwermans]], wholly in favour of the former. In that partial article much is said of his extreme devotion to art, of his marvelous knowledge of anatomy, of his special fondness for the English racehorses, and his excellence in depicting them. He appears first in the Academy catalogues in 1801 as the exhibitor of the 'Portrait of a Horse', and continued to exhibit more or less until 1845 (contradicting Nagler's statement that he died "about" 1806).
In the catalogues his name is given as J.L. Agasse or Agassé. The number of times Agassé changed his address confirms Redgrave's assertion that "he lived poor and died poor". The writer of the panegyric already quoted says, however, that he did not work for money, but that he was urged forward by the resistless force of natural genius.
He is also featured in the French thriller ''[[L'Antiquaire]]'', with some works credited to him—a painting of two Leopards, among others.

==Details== Sir [[John Luttrell (soldier)|John Luttrell]] was an English [[soldier]], [[diplomat]], and [[courtier]] under [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] and [[Edward VI of England|Edward VI]]. The Flemish artist [[Hans Eworth]] produced a portrait of him in 1550, noted for its use of allegorical images. The painting shows John shaking his fist at a woman carrying an [[olive]] branch, while a ship founders on a stormy sea in the background. The painting is thought to represent John's anger at the peace treaty of 1550 between England and France; the ship is probably the ''Mary of Hamburg'', which served under John during one of his Scottish campaigns.<ref name=GarnettP9>Garnett, p.9.</ref> Historian Oliver Garnett considers the painting to be "one of the most unusual and puzzling of all Tudor images".<ref name=GarnettP9/>
The painting is now owned by the [[Courtauld Institute of Art]] in [[London]]; a copy, made in 1591, hangs at [[Dunster Castle]] in [[Somerset]].<ref name=GarnettP9/>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== *Garnett, Oliver. (2003) ''Dunster Castle, Somerset.''London: The National Trust. {{ISBN|978-1-84359-049-1}}.

:''For the Danish progressive pop/soul band, see [[Julias Moon]]'' {{Infobox Korean name |img= |caption= |hangul=문훈숙 |hanja= |rr=Mun Hun-suk |mr=Mun Hun-suk |}} '''Julia H. Moon''' also known as '''Hoon Sook Moon''' (born '''Hoon Sook Pak''', January 1, 1963<ref>Birthday according to the Gregorian (solar) calendar rather than the lunar calendar often used in east Asia. [http://www.tparents.org/UNews/PDF/Unws0112.pdf Unification News, December 2001, Volume 20, No. 12]</ref>) is the General Director of [[Universal Ballet]] in [[South Korea]], and daughter-in-law of [[Sun Myung Moon]], founder of the ballet company.<ref name="black">{{cite news | last =Black | first =Robert | title =Moon and his ballet stars: When the Rev Moon's son died in a car crash, the controversial religious leader formed a dance company for the young man's fiancee. With money no object, it has impressed critics around the world | work =[[The Daily Telegraph]] | date =October 26, 2000 }}</ref> She was the [[prima ballerina]] of the company.
==Biography==
===Early life=== Julia Moon was born in 1963 in [[Washington, D.C.]], as Hoon Sook Pak.<ref name="rising">{{cite news | title =Arts: Ballet's star is rising in the east: The Universal Ballet dance by the light of the Reverend Moon. But it's not only the devout who will enjoy the Korean company's production of Giselle | work =[[The Independent]] | page =8; Section: Features | date =October 28, 2000 }}</ref><ref name="uproar">{{cite news | last =Isikoff | first =Michael | title =Theological uproar in Unification Church - Rev. Moon recognizes Zimbabwean as his reincarnated son | work =[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73578904.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Mar+30%2C+1988&author=Michael+Isikoff&pub=The+Washington+Post+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&edition=&startpage=a.01&desc=Theological+Uproar+in+Unification+Church%3BRev.+Moon+Recognizes+Zimbabwean+as+His+Reincarnated+Son | page =A1 | date =March 30, 1988 }}</ref><ref name="english">{{cite news | last =English | first =Susan | title =Lake dance: Universal Ballet of Korea stops off in Spokane for 'Swan Lake' | work =[[The Spokesman-Review]] | page =D3 | date =March 12, 1998 }}</ref> Her father, [[Bo Hi Pak]], is a senior leader in the [[Unification Church]]<ref name="black" /> and has been responsible for [[News World Communications]] (which published ''[[The Washington Times]]''), [[CAUSA International]], the [[Little Angels Children's Folk Ballet of Korea]], and other church related organizations.<ref name="fried" /> At the age of 10, Julia Moon traveled to Korea to receive dance instruction with the Little Angels, which had been founded in 1962 by Sun Myung Moon.<ref name="watts" /> She performed as a singer and dancer with them.<ref>{{cite news | last =Salisbury | first =Wilma | title =Korea's Little Angels spread wings globally | work =[[The Plain Dealer]]|location=[[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] | page =02I | date =January 14, 2001}}</ref> "At first, I was interested in gymnastics. Then I wanted to dance, but when I realized how much hard work it involved, I wanted to change. But my parents were very encouraging about me continuing with ballet," she said.<ref name="watts" /> She took courses in ballet at the [[Sun Hwa Arts School]] in Seoul, and subsequently received instruction at the [[Royal Ballet School]] in [[London]] and [[L'Academie de Dance Classique de Princess Grace of Monaco]].<ref name="watts" /> She was a dancer with the [[Ohio Ballet]], and the [[Washington Ballet]];<ref name="watts" /> joining the latter in 1982.<ref name="rising" />
===Universal Ballet=== After her [[fiancé]] [[Heung Jin Moon]] died in an [[automobile accident]], Sun Myung Moon founded a dance company for her.<ref name="black" /><ref name="uproar" /> She had been engaged to Sun Myung Moon's 17-year-old son, who died in 1984.<ref name="black" /> She was previously known as Julia Pak, and was already a gifted ballet performer prior to the incident.<ref name="black" /> "We had no definite date for a marriage but it was implicit that we would be together. Rev Moon had suggested us but we had made the decision," she said of her fiancé.<ref name="express">{{cite news | title =I loved my fiancée so much, I married him after he died | work =[[The Express]] | date =October 28, 2000 }}</ref> In a ceremony, she was married to the spirit of Sun Myung Moon's son after his death, and became Moon's daughter-in-law.<ref name="black" /><ref>{{cite news | last =Kaufman | first =Sarah | title =Universal Ballet's Really Big Show |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/74115577.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jun+15%2C+2001&author=Sarah+Kaufman&pub=The+Washington+Post&edition=&startpage=C.07&desc=Universal+Ballet%27s+Really+Big+Show | work =[[The Washington Post]] | page =C7; Section: Style | date =June 15, 2001 }}</ref> This was in accordance with Unification Church beliefs that only people who are married may enter into [[heaven]].<ref name="fried" /><ref>{{cite news | last =Nix | first =Shann | title =Moon Church Goes Partners With Kirov in New Academy | work =[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | page =A1 | date =May 11, 1990}}</ref> She had been performing overseas with the Washington Ballet, but was called back to the United States in order to be spiritually married to Heung Jin Nim.<ref>{{cite news | last =Kastor | first =Elizabeth | title =The Ballet Project - Unification Church renovates building for dance | work =[[The Washington Post]] | url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73624355.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Aug+19%2C+1988&author=Elizabeth+Kastor&pub=The+Washington+Post+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&edition=&startpage=c.01&desc=The+Ballet+Project%3B+Unification+Church+Renovates+Building+for+Dance | page =C1 | date =August 19, 1988 }}</ref> The marriage to her husband's spirit is believed to be "permanent and indissoluble".<ref>{{cite news | last =Johnson | first =Robert | title =Moon over Korea - Ballet troupe founded by controversial cleric | work =[[The Star-Ledger]] | page =23 | date =July 27, 2001}}</ref>
She explained to ''[[The Evening Standard]]'' about getting married to a groom already deceased, "In Korean tradition, I've heard there are other cases of this kind of marriage. In our church, my case is the only one where it's happened this way. But even if this personal situation had not happened, the company would still have got started."<ref name="hutera">{{cite news | last =Hutera | first =Donald | title =Toeing The Moonie Line | work =[[The Evening Standard]] | date =October 26, 2000 }}</ref> Julia Moon commented to ''[[Dance Magazine]]'' on her relationship with her husband, "When I dance, I'm communicating with my husband. He's not here physically, but he's close in spirit."<ref name="english" /> She stated she "had a son with Jin" through adoption of her sister's son.<ref name="english" /> "I have an adopted son, aged eight. My husband's younger brother's family wanted to offer me their child," she said to ''The Evening Standard'' in 2000.<ref name="hutera" />
The Universal Ballet company of South Korea was founded to serve as a memorial to her husband.<ref name="black" /> Universal Ballet of [[Seoul]], Korea was founded in 1984, and the Universal Ballet Foundation, Inc. was started by the Unification Church in 1986.<ref name="fried">{{cite news | last =Fried | first =Dayna Lynn | title =Critics fear dance academy is a cover to recruit Moonies | work =[[The San Diego Union]] | page =B-1 | date =May 18, 1990 }}</ref> Located in [[Washington, D.C.]], the Universal Ballet Foundation, Inc. operates as a casting office for the Universal Ballet of Korea.<ref name="fried" /> The dance company was initially started by Bo Hi Pak and ballerina [[Adrienne Dellas]].<ref name="hutera" /><ref name="yolen">{{cite book | last =Yolen | first =Jane |author2=Heidi E. Y. Stemple | title =The Barefoot Book of Ballet Stories | publisher =Barefoot Books | year =2004 | page =60 | isbn = 1-84148-229-3}}</ref> Dellas had previously served as a dance instructor for Julia Moon.<ref name="yolen" /> Julia Moon's father served as president of Universal Ballet as of 2000; he was also chairman of the Korean Cultural Foundation.<ref name="black" /> At its inception, Julia Moon was the primal ballerina of Universal Ballet.<ref name="yolen" /> In 1986, Julia Moon performed as the lead ballerina dancer at a performance based on a Korean folk tale called ''Shim Chung'', in a production at the Asian Games, Culture and Arts Festival in [[Seoul]].<ref name="yolen" /> ''Shim Chung'' went on to become a popular performance piece in South Korea.<ref name="yolen" />
In December 1989, Julia Moon made her debut with the [[Kirov Ballet]] in [[Leningrad]] in a performance of ''[[Giselle]]''.<ref name="eagle">{{cite news | last =Compiled from Eagle staff and wire reports | title =Moon having Kirov debut | work =[[The Wichita Eagle]]|location=[[Wichita, Kansas]] | page =1C | date =December 22, 1989 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Griffith | first =Dorsey | title =Ballet folks nervous about Rev. Moon's step into dance world | work =[[The Modesto Bee]] | page =D-1 | date =June 19, 1990 }}</ref> To promote the performance, Sun Myung Moon took out a full-page advertisement in ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name="eagle" /> The ad featured an image of Sun Myung Moon.<ref name="eagle" /> It also contained the text of an interview with Sun Myung Moon by a Soviet reporter, where Moon said the ballet was "an important moment in the development of my personal contact with the Soviet Union".<ref name="eagle" /> Sun Myung Moon created the Kirov Academy of Ballet in Northeast for Julia, and recruited Oleg Vinogradov of the Kirov Ballet in Russia to serve as artistic director;<ref>{{cite news | last =Fisher | first =Marc |author2=Jeff Leen | title =A Church in flux is flush with cash - Moon linked to bewildering array of entities | work =[[The Washington Post]] | url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/23207785.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Nov+23%2C+1997&author=Marc+Fisher%3BJeff+Leen&pub=The+Washington+Post&edition=&startpage=A.01&desc=A+Church+in+Flux+Is+Flush+With+Cash%3B+Moon+Linked+to+Bewildering+Array+of+Entities+Series%3A+MOON+INC.%3B+TROUBLED+CHURCH%2C+THRIVING+BUSINESS+Series+Number%3A+1%2F2 | page =A1 | date =November 23, 1997 }}</ref> Vinogradov was appointed to the role in 1998.<ref>{{cite news | last =Weiss | first =Hedy | title =Keeping Kirov Ballet tradition alive | work =[[Chicago Sun-Times]] | page =35 | date =April 25, 2000 }}</ref>
In 1990, the founder of the Washington Ballet [[Mary Day]] commented to ''[[The New York Times]]'' about Julia Moon, "She's a lovely, lovely girl, and a lovely dancer and person. We were sorry to lose her when she went back to Korea to start the company."<ref>{{cite news | last =Dunning | first =Jennifer (''[[The New York Times]]'') | title = Moon's ballet school - New non-sectarian academy offers dancers lavish surroundings in Washington | work =[[Houston Chronicle]] | page =12 | date =September 13, 1990}}</ref> As of 1990 the Universal Ballet company had yet to perform in the [[United States]], but had hired guest performers from the U.S. at significant cost.<ref>{{cite news | last =Goldner | first =Nancy | title =Russian ballet school in D.C., from Rev. Moon | work =[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] | page = G01 | date =October 28, 1990 }}</ref>
In a 1993 interview with ''[[Tulsa World]]'', Julia Moon said of the art of ballet, "It's really a universal language."<ref name="watts">{{cite news | last =Watts Jr. | first =James D. | title =Moon Dance - Korean-American Julia Moon Puts Lyrical Touch on Tulsa Ballet's `Paquita' | work =[[Tulsa World]] | page =E1 | date =September 17, 1993 }}</ref> She spoke of Korean dancers versus other styles, "I think I would say that Korean dancers - those born and raised there - are very lyrical in their movements, more so than Japanese or Chinese or American dancers," she said. "It's probably something related to Korean folk dancing, which uses a very soft line and is very lyrical."<ref name="watts" /> In 1995, Julia Moon started her term as the general director of the Universal Ballet company.<ref name="romeo">{{cite news | last =Paluch | first =Vicki Smith| title =Romeo, what art thou? - Universal Ballet's version of the Shakespeare tale takes liberties with the story to emphasize the dancing | work =[[Long Beach Press-Telegram]] | page =U16 | date =August 8, 2004 }}</ref>
The Universal Ballet company's first tour in the United States was in 1998.<ref name="bleiberg">{{cite news | last =Bleiberg | first =Laura | title =Troupe seeks a U.S. toehold - Dance: The Universal Ballet of Korea, which favors full-length story ballets and Russian style, launches a tour. | work =[[The Orange County Register]] | page =F04 | date =March 11, 1998 }}</ref> Julia Moon said that the company is separate from Sun Myung Moon, and that only herself and one other member are also members of the Unification Church.<ref name="bleiberg" /> Approximately half of the administrative staff, headed by her father, Bo Hi Pak, one of Rev. Moon's chief aides, belong to the Unification Church.<ref>{{cite news| last = Robertson| first = Allen | title =Dance: A Small Place Reaches for Ballet's Big Time | work = [[The New York Times]] | date =July 29, 2001 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/29/arts/dance-a-small-place-reaches-for-ballet-s-big-time.html| accessdate = 2009-12-26 }}</ref> She said the company does not perform modern ballet styles, due to her view that the "classical form is the most beautiful form and therefore that's where our background is".<ref name="bleiberg" /> She commented that she would like for the company to move in the direction of more contemporary pieces, "We really do want to know more of these contemporary modern works. I think we're ready for it. We need to expand artistically in that area, as well as keeping parallel with the classical tradition."<ref name="bleiberg" />
In 2000, Julia Moon was interviewed by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' on her thoughts about being the general director of Universal Ballet.<ref name="black" /> "I lack certain qualities, as a dancer and as a director. Sometimes I do wish I was a nobody, but because this company was formed on me, I feel that if I faltered or wavered the company would falter as well," she said.<ref name="black" /> She commented in 2000 to ''The Evening Standard'' about [[homosexuality]] in ballet, "It exists in Korea, but since we started 16 years ago we haven't had any gay dancers. We just haven't had to deal with that issue."<ref name="hutera" />
In 2001, the Universal Ballet company performed ''Shim Chung'' in [[California]].<ref name="knaff">{{cite news | last =Knaff | first =Deborah L. | title =Ballet and Korea come together Dance: The Seoul-based Universal Ballet has gained critical acclaim for its classicism. | work =[[The Press-Enterprise]] | page =AA20 | date =July 13, 2001}}</ref> Julia Moon commented to ''[[The Press-Enterprise]]'' on the selection of ''Shim Chung'' as the performance piece, "We thought that this would be a good ballet to bring with us on this tour. We are very proud of it and we think that it is a very beautiful ballet. But beyond that I believe it demonstrates in the most convincing way possible that classical ballet and Korean literary and dance traditions can come together to create a new dance form, a blend in which each of the parts has its place."<ref name="knaff" /> She to ''[[The Press-Telegram]]'' in 2001 that at this point Universal Ballet was judged more for its artistic merit than its origins, "People are now judging us by our artistry. The press is less interested in the connection with the church. The church has no role in the ballet company. I am a member of the church, as is one other dancer."<ref>{{cite news | last =Paluch | first =Vicki Smith | title =Global inspirations - A Korean ballet company looks to Russia for its repertoire | work =[[The Press-Telegram]] | page =W7 | date =July 20, 2001}}</ref> In 2002, Julia Moon retired from her position as the star of the Universal Ballet company.<ref>{{cite news | last =Hunt | first =Mary Ellen | title =Universal's talent is deep, but muddled - The Korean ballet company's dancers are hampered by the lack of cohesion in this 'Romeo' | work =[[Contra Costa Times]]|location= [[Walnut Creek, California]] | page =C3 | date =August 16, 2004 }}</ref>
In 2004, the Universal Ballet company performed ''[[La Bayadere]]'' at the Sejong Center for the Performing Arts in Korea.<ref name="warrenlee" /> "The ballet is known for its spectacle. It's mammoth, visually grand and one of the more exotic ballets in the repertory," explained Julia Moon.<ref name="warrenlee" /> By 2004, she had become artistic director of Universal Ballet.<ref name="warrenlee">{{cite news | last =Lee | first =Warren | title =Love and betrayal in legendary India | work =[[The Korean Herald]] | date =February 24, 2004 }}</ref> In 2004, Bo Hi Pak was the chairman of the board of directors of the Universal Ballet company.<ref name="romeo" /> According to the ''[[Long Beach Press-Telegram]]'', "[Julia Moon's] role as general director had been at times overshadowed by the strong presence and energy of the Rev. Moon, and Pak, both of whom share a desire to create a world-class ballet company for Korea."<ref name="romeo" /> In 2008, the Unification Church still gave financial support to the Universal Ballet company, and Julia Moon had a position on the company's board of directors.<ref>{{cite news | last = Holley | first = Joe | title = Ballet School Founder Yelena Vinogradova | work = [[The Washington Post]] | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/06/28/AR2008062801925.html | page =C8; Section: Metro | date = June 29, 2008}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

:''For the agricultural/topographic term see [[Keyline design]]''
A '''keyline''', in [[graphic design]], is a boundary line that separates color and [[monochromatic]] areas or differently colored areas of printing on a given page or other printed piece.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://labelprintingportland.com/keyline/|title=What is a keyline and why we use them - Rose City Label|date=2013-08-16|work=Rose City Label|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US}}</ref> The line itself, usually consisting of a black (or other dark colored) border, provides an area in which lighter colors can be printed with slight variation in registration. In traditional [[paste-up]] graphics workflows, keylines for cropping were often merely indicated on original artwork, and then images were stripped into the area manually with the keylines themselves being added as part of the process. Keylines are often included when printing something that will be cut out using a die form, requires folding, or uses perforation lines.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://indesignsecrets.com/creating-keylines.php|title=Creating Keylines - InDesignSecrets.com|date=2015-12-07|work=InDesignSecrets|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
Per the [[International Paper]]'s Pocket Pal (18th ed., printed in 2000), keyline is defined as being "in artwork, an outline drawing of finished art to indicate the exact shape, position, and size for elements such as [[halftones]], line sketches, etc."<ref>{{cite book |last=Bruno |first=Michael H. |date=October 2000 |title= Pocket Pal: A Graphic Arts Production Handbook (18th Edition) |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hbNBPgAACAAJ |publisher=International Paper Company |page=199 |isbn=978-0883623381 }}</ref>

The '''Kiri Te Kanawa Foundation''' is a charitable foundation set up by the celebrated opera [[soprano]] [[Kiri Te Kanawa]] to help music students.
==Vision== The vision of the Kiri Te Kanawa Foundation is that talented young New Zealand singers and musicians with complete dedication to their art may receive judicious and thoughtful mentoring and support to assist them in realising their dreams.
The Foundation's mission is to establish, build and manage a trust fund to provide financial and career support to such talented New Zealanders. The first person to be awarded a grant under the trust was the young Dunedin born soprano [[Ana James]].
==External links== *[http://www.kiritekanawa.org Official website]
{{Kiri Te Kanawa}}

The '''Leuven Database of Ancient Books''' (LDAB) is a resource for all ancient written literary manuscripts, from 500 BC to AD 800. It currently lists more than 16.000 [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Latin language|Latin]], [[Coptic language|Coptic]], [[Syriac language|Syriac]] and [[Demotic (Egyptian)|Demotic]] literary texts. It "attempts to collect the basic information on all ancient literary texts".<ref>{{Cite book | last = Parker| first =David C. | authorlink = David C. Parker | title =An Introduction to the NT Manuscripts and Their Texts | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/27105968/An-Introduction-to-the-NT-Manuscripts-and-Their-Texts | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge | year=2008 | pages = 47 }} </ref> It includes authors from [[Homer]] to [[Gregory the Great]] and more than 3.600 texts of unidentified authors.<ref>[http://www.trismegistos.org/ldab/about.php Leuven Database of Ancient Books] Trismegistos </ref>
It was founded in 1998 at the [[KU Leuven]] by Willy Clarysse.

This is a list of artists who create [[contemporary art]], i.e., those whose peak of activity can be situated somewhere between the 1970s (the advent of [[postmodernism]]) and the present day. Artists on this list meet the following criteria: *The person is regarded as an important figure or is widely cited by his/her peers or successors. *The person is known for originating a significant new concept, theory or technique. *The person has created, or played a major role in co-creating, a significant or well-known work, or collective body of work, that has been the subject of an independent book or feature-length film, or of multiple independent periodical articles or reviews. *The person's work either (a) has become a significant monument, (b) has been a substantial part of a significant exhibition, (c) has won significant critical attention, or (d) is represented within the permanent collections of several notable galleries or museums, or had works in many significant libraries.

'''Macedonian Renaissance''' is a label sometimes used to describe the period of the [[Macedonian dynasty]] of the [[Byzantine Empire]] (867–1056), especially the 10th century, which some scholars have seen as a time of increased interest in classical scholarship and the assimilation of classical motifs into [[Christian art]]work.
[[File:Apse mosaic Hagia Sophia Virgin and Child.jpg|thumb|180px|Virgin with child mosaic, [[Hagia Sophia]]]] [[File:Hosios Loukas Katholikon 20091116-33.JPG|thumb|180px|Interior of [[Hosios Loukas]]]]
== Concept == Because of problems with the term, scholars have employed alternative names to describe this period, including "renaissance" (with a small "r"), "renascence",<ref>{{cite book | last = Cormack | first = Robin | title = Byzantine Art | publisher =Oxford University Press | location= Oxford | year = 2000 | page=131 | isbn =0-19-284211-0}}</ref> '''Middle Byzantine Renaissance''' or '''First Byzantine Renaissance''' (the [[Palaeologan Renaissance]] from the 13th century on being the second). [[Macedonian art (Byzantine)|Macedonian art]] refers to the art of this period.
Because the word [[Renaissance]] (''rinascita'') was created in the 15th and 16th centuries by Italian humanists to describe their own time, its use outside of that context is problematic; however, the period in question certainly did produce ideas and works of art that reflected a reassessment of classical ideals.<ref>For a discussion on the topic, see Cormack, ''Byzantine Art'', pp. 130-142.</ref>
The term ''Macedonian Renaissance'' was first used by Kurt Weitzmann in his ''The Joshua Roll: A Work of the Macedonian Renaissance''.<ref>Weitzmann, Kurt. ''The Joshua Roll: A Work of the Macedonian Renaissance.'' Studies in Manuscript Illumination III, Princeton: Princeton Univ. Press, 1948.</ref> It describes the architecture of Macedonia. At the same time, the manuscripts of "Paris Psalter" (cod. gr. 139, Paris, Bib. Nat. de France) were indicated as the best examples of Macedonian Renaissance by scholars.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Paris Psalterionu (Cod. gr. 139, Paris-Ulusal Kütüphane) ve Makedonyan Rönesansı (full paper text)|url = https://www.academia.edu/16355712/Paris_Psalterionu_Cod._gr._139_Paris-Ulusal_K%25C3%25BCt%25C3%25BCphane_ve_Makedonyan_R%25C3%25B6nesans%25C4%25B1_full_paper_text_|website = www.academia.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-01}}</ref>
== Era == The term “Byzantine” arose from [[Byzantium]], a city founded in the eighth century BC on the site that would become [[Constantinople]] and is now [[Istanbul]]. Being on the easternmost territory of the Roman Empire allowed the groundwork for the Macedonian Renaissance to come about. [[Latin]] was the imperial language of law and government while [[Ancient Greek]] was the language of its literature and the religion was [[Orthodox Christianity]].<ref>. The Oxford Handbook of Byzantine Studies edited by Elizabeth Jeffreys with John Haldon and Robin Cormack. Published 2008 by Oxford University Press.</ref>
While the [[West Roman Empire]] had collapsed at the outset of the [[Middle Ages]], its Eastern half, the [[Byzantine Empire|Eastern Roman Empire]], was able to survive and flourish. This was due mainly to its strategic location for commerce but also to the way it was able to hold back its enemies. [[Basil I]] (867-886), the founder of the [[Macedonian Dynasty]] of Byzantine rulers, was born in [[Byzantine Thrace|Thrace]] to a peasant family said to be of [[Armenians|Armenian]] descent. He was employed in the influential circles of Constantinople and was rapidly promoted by the emperor [[Michael III]] eventually becoming co-emperor.<ref>"Basil I". Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica Online.Encyclopædia Britannica Inc., 2012. Web. 13 May. 2012 <https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/55030/Basil-I>.</ref>
By means of political maneuvering he was able to secure his future as emperor and then began military and diplomatic campaigns to secure the empire. He was able to regain control over [[Crete]] and [[Cyprus]] at the same time he was able to hold back [[First Bulgar Empire|Bulgarian]] advances into his territory. His dynasty was thus able to maintain a period of peace under which economics, philosophy, art, and culture could thrive.
This period produced a shift from the [[Byzantine Iconoclasm|ban on the painting]] of religious figures to [[icon]]s being painted to reflect the more classical and naturalistic influences of art on the culture. [[Mosaic]]s such as the [[Virgin and Child]] in [[Hagia Sophia]] can still be seen today. The new style of art may have inspired Italian artists such as [[Cimabue]] and [[Giotto]]<ref>[http://www.medieval-life-and-times.info/medieval-art/byzantine-art.htm Byzantine art]</ref> before the [[Italian Renaissance]].
The period also saw a proliferation of literature, such as ''[[De Ceremoniis]]'' ("The Book of Ceremonies"), which focused on governance, diplomatic interactions with neighboring nations, and other customs of the time. Education had also become a priority once again and the [[University of Constantinople]] boasted scholars such as [[Michael Psellus]], who wrote the ''Chronographia'', a history of fourteen Byzantine rulers. Meanwhile, reforms in law sought to limit the power and growth of large land owners by the formation of trade guilds that allowed the state to control growth as described in the [[Book of the Eparch]].
<!--TO BE ENHANCED TO A SCIENCE SECTION??:-->The building [[Magnaura]] in [[Constantinople]] had already become a school in 849 and was headed by the philosopher [[Leo the Mathematician]] (c. 790 – after 869).<ref>[http://www.macedonian-heritage.gr/HellenicMacedonia/en/EC.2.3a.html macedonian-heritage.gr: Leon the Mathematician]</ref> Most of his works are lost.

'''Persian pottery''' or '''Iranian pottery''' refers to the pottery works made by the artists of [[Persia|Persia (Iran)]] and its history goes back to early [[Neolithic Age]] (7th millennium BCE).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://researcharchive.calacademy.org/research/anthropology/persia/history.htm |title=The History of Persian Ceramics |publisher=California Academy of Sciences |date=2010-02-02 |accessdate=2014-07-09}}</ref>
Through the centuries, Persian potters have responded to the demands and changes brought by political turmoil by adopting and refining newly introduced forms and blending them into their own culture. This innovative attitude has survived through time and influenced many other cultures around the world.
The Islamic prohibition on using vessels made of precious metal at the table, which had been usual for pre-Islamic elites of the earlier [[Persian empire]]s, meant that a market for luxury ceramics opened up, which Persian potters were able to fill with fancy glazes such as in [[lustreware]] and high-quality painted decoration.
==Early pottery from Susa== {{main|Susa}} Evidence of a painted-pottery civilization around [[Susa]] has been dated to c 5000 BCE.<ref name=Langer>{{cite book|title=An Encyclopedia of World History| editor-last = Langer | editor-first = William L. |edition = 5th | publisher = Houghton Mifflin Company| location = Boston, MA| year = 1972 | isbn = 0-395-13592-3|pages = 17}}</ref> Susa was firmly within the [[Sumer]]ian [[Uruk]] cultural sphere during the [[Uruk period]]. An imitation of the entire state apparatus of Uruk, [[proto-writing]], [[cylinder seal]]s with Sumerian motifs, and monumental architecture, is found at Susa. Susa may have been a colony of Uruk. As such, the [[periodization]] of Susa corresponds to Uruk; Early, Middle and Late Susa II periods (3800–3100 BCE) correspond to Early, Middle, and Late Uruk periods.
Shortly after Susa was first settled 6000 years ago, its inhabitants erected a temple on a monumental platform that rose over the flat surrounding landscape. The exceptional nature of the site is still recognizable today in the artistry of the ceramic vessels that were placed as offerings in a thousand or more graves near the base of the temple platform. Nearly two thousand pots were recovered from the cemetery and now, most of them now are located in the [[Louvre]]; one such vessel is the [[Bushel with ibex motifs]]. The vessels found are eloquent testimony to the artistic and technical achievements of their makers, and they hold clues about the organization of the society that commissioned them.<ref name="Aruz 1992 26">{{cite book|last=Aruz|first=Joan|title=The Royal City of Susa: Ancient Near Eastern Treasures in the Louvre|year=1992|publisher=Abrams|location=New York|page=26}}</ref> Painted ceramic vessels from Susa in the earliest first style are a late, regional version of the Mesopotamian [[Ubaid period|Ubaid]] ceramic tradition that spread across the Near East during the fifth millennium B.C.<ref name="Aruz 1992 26"/>
Susa I style was very much a product of the past and of influences from contemporary ceramic industries in the mountains of western Iran. The recurrence in close association of vessels of three types—a drinking goblet or beaker, a serving dish, and a small jar—implies the consumption of three types of food, apparently thought to be as necessary for life in the afterworld as it is in this one. Ceramics of these shapes, which were painted, constitute a large proportion of the vessels from the cemetery. Others are course cooking-type jars and bowls with simple bands painted on them and were probably the grave goods of the sites of humbler citizens as well as adolescents and, perhaps, children.<ref>{{cite book|last=Aruz|first=Joan|title=The Royal City of Susa: Ancient Near Eastern Treasures in the Louvre|year=1992|publisher=Abrams|location=New York|page=29}}</ref> The pottery is carefully made by hand. Although a slow wheel may have been employed, the asymmetry of the vessels and the irregularity of the drawing of encircling lines and bands indicate that most of the work was done freehand.
==Early Islamic period== The [[Samanid Empire|Samanid period]] saw the creation of epigraphic pottery. These pieces were typically [[earthenware]] vessels with black [[Slip (ceramics)|slip]] lettering in [[Kufic|Kufi]] script painted on a base of white slip. These vessels would typically be inscribed with benedictions or adages.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McWilliams|first1=Mary|title=Bowl Inscribed with a Saying of 'Ali ibn Abi Talib|url=http://www.harvardartmuseums.org/art/165532|website=Harvard Art Museums|accessdate=7 July 2015}}</ref> [[Samarqand]] and [[Nishapur]] were both centers of production for this kind of pottery.<ref name="Volov 1966">{{cite journal|last1=Volov|first1=Lis|title=Plaited Kufic on Samanid Epigraphic Pottery|journal=Ars Orientalis|date=1966|volume=6|issue=1966|page=107-33}}</ref>
Innovations in ceramics from this period include the production of minai ware, enamelled with figures on a white background, and use [[fritware]], a [[silicon]]-based paste, rather than clay.<ref>Piotrovsky & Rogers, 64–73</ref> Metalworkers highlighted their intricate hammered designs with precious metal inlays.<ref>Piotrovsky & Rogers, 78–93</ref>
One potter, [[Abū Zayd ibn Muḥammad ibn Abī Zayd]] (active c. 1186 – 1219, [[Kashan]]) has signed 15 surviving pieces, more than any other medieval Iranian potter.<ref>[http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T000296 "Abu Zayd."] In Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online, (accessed February 5, 2012; subscription required).</ref>
==Safavid period== [[Image:Plate pomegranates Louvre MAO868.jpg|thumb|right|''Plate decorated with two pomegranates'', v. 1500, [[the Louvre]]]] [[Image:Tile young man flowers - Iran - Louvre museum - AD 27812.jpg|thumb|Tile with young man. Earthenware, painted on slip and under transparent glaze. Northwestern Iran, [[Kubachi ware]], 17th century.]] The study and dating of ceramics under [[Shah Ismail]] and [[Shah Tahmasp]] is difficult because there are few pieces which are dated or which mention the place of production. [[Chinese porcelain]] was collected by the elite, and was more highly valued than the local productions; Shah Abbas I donated much of the royal collection to the shrines at [[Ardabil]] and [[Mashhad]], renovating a room at Ardabil to display pieces in niches.<ref>Canby (2009), 101-104, 121-123, 137-159</ref> Many locations of workshops have been identified, although not with certainty, in particular: [[Nishapur]], [[Kubachi ware]], [[Kerman]] (moulded monochromatic pieces) and Mashhad. [[Lusterware]] was revived, using a different technique from the earlier production, and typically making small pieces with a design in a dark copper colour over a dark blue background. Unlike other wares, these use traditional Middle Eastern shapes and decoration rather than Chinese-inspired ones.<ref>Blair & Bloom, 171</ref>
In general, the designs tend to imitate those of Chinese porcelain, with the production of blue and white pieces with Chinese form and motifs, with motifs such as chi clouds, and dragons.<ref>Blair & Bloom, 171</ref> The [[Persian blue]] is distinguished from the [[Chinese blue]] by its more numerous and subtle nuances. Often, quatrains by Persian poets, sometimes related to the destination of the piece (allusion to wine for a goblet, for example) occur in the scroll patterns. A completely different type of design, much more rare, carries iconography very specific to Islam (Islamic zodiac, bud scales, [[arabesque (Islamic art)|arabesques]]) and seems influenced by the Ottoman world, as is evidenced by feather-edged anthemions (honeysuckle ornaments) widely used in Turkey. New styles of figures appeared, influenced by the art of the book: young, elegant cupbearers, young women with curved silhouettes, or yet cypress trees entangling their branches, reminiscent of the paintings of [[Reza Abbasi]].
Numerous types of pieces were produced: goblets, plates, long-necked bottles, [[spittoon]]s, etc. A common shape is flasks with very small necks and bodies flattened on one side and very rounded on the other. Shapes borrowed from Islamic metalwork with decoration largely inspired by Chinese porcelain are characteristic.<ref>Canby (2009), 162-163, 218-219</ref> With the closing of the Chinese market in 1659, Persian ceramic soared to new heights, to fulfill European needs. The appearance of false marks of Chinese workshops on the backs of some ceramics marked the taste that developed in Europe for far-eastern porcelain, satisfied in large part by Safavid production. This new destination led to wider use of Chinese and exotic iconography (elephants) and the introduction of new forms, sometimes astonishing ([[hookah]]s, octagonal plates, animal-shaped objects).
== Contemporary == One of the main areas in Iran that has a very special way of producing pottery is Kalpuregan. Kalpuregan village is located in south east of Iran. The only characteristic that distinguishes Kalpuregan from other areas is its indigenous pottery, creation of civilization by Baluchi women artists. According to one of the village elders, manufacturing practices dating back to about 4 to 6 thousand years ago still remains intact. The only workshop that is still active and persistent to continue working with primitive method is Kalpuregan pottery workshop.
Throughout the history the art of pottery in Kalpuregan has belonged to women since men had the burden of hunting or farming. According to historical evidence, indigenous women are creators of pottery art. In this land, delicate tasks are done by women and men only have the responsibility of preparing and firimg the clay.
Another thing that distinguishes pottery of the region from other parts of the country is that women in Kalpuregan do not use pottery wheel to make pottery. It is amazing that such a magnificent work is possible only with traditional and innovative methods and the help of rural women's loving cracked hands. Potteries in this area learn this art from their mothers or clan women.
Paintings on pottery are abstract symbols that remained from generation to generation and indicate the artist’s beliefs and spiritual desires of her surroundings. Often symbolic paintings are similar to early prehistoric pottery. Indigenous artist women in this area believe they should use simple and abstract geometric patterns to paint pottery pieces exactly like their Ancestors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.farwayart.com/blog/indigenous-pottery-in-kalpuregan-iran|title=Indigenous pottery in Kalpuregan (Iran)|last=Art|first=Far Way|website=Far Way Art|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
==Collections== There are large collections of Persian pottery at the [[British Museum]], the [[Hermitage Museum]], the [[Royal Ontario Museum]], and elsewhere. In 2013, the Royal Ontario Museum, in partnership with [[Brill Publishers]] in the [[Netherlands]], published a special book about this art entitled "Persian Pottery in the First Global Age".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brill.com/products/book/persian-pottery-first-global-age |title=Persian Pottery in the First Global Age |publisher=Brill/ROM |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}}</ref> {{Persian arts}} ==Notes== {{Reflist}}

(ed), 2009, ''Shah Abbas; The Remaking of Iran'', 2009, British Museum Press, {{ISBN|9780714124520}} *Piotrovsky M.B. and Rogers, J.M. {{short description|painting by Jan Mostaert}} {{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=File:African man portrait Mostaert.jpg | alt=See adjacent text. | image_size=250px | title=Portrait of an African Man | other_language_1=[[Dutch language|Dutch]] | other_title_1=Portret van een Afrikaanse man | artist=[[Jan Mostaert]] | year={{circa}} 1525–1530 | type=[[Oil painting|Oil]] on [[oak]] | height_metric=30.8 | width_metric=21.2 | city=Amsterdam | museum=[[Rijksmuseum]] }}
The '''''Portrait of an African Man''''' ({{lang-nl|Portret van een Afrikaanse man}}) also known as '''''Portrait of a Moor''''' ({{lang-nl|Portret van een Moor}}) is a painting by the [[Dutch and Flemish Renaissance painting|Netherlandish Renaissance painter]] [[Jan Mostaert]]. Mostaert probably made the painting between c. 1525 and 1530, or slightly earlier. The exact subject of the painting has long been unclear, although numerous ideas have been put forward, including that the depicted figure is a soldier, a nobleman or [[Saint Maurice]]. The portrait is significant in that it may portray the earliest portrait of a specific black man in European painting,<ref>{{cite web|author=Sosha Lemmen|url=http://dspace.library.uu.nl/handle/1874/251873|title=Ambassadeurs van het christendom – De representatieve en (politiek-)missionaire functies van portretten van zwarte mannen en vrouwen uit de 16de en vroege 17de eeuw|language=Dutch|date=1 February 2012|accessdate=24 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=rijksmuseum>{{cite web|url=https://www.rijksmuseum.nl/en/collection/SK-A-4986|title=Portrait of an African Man (Christophle le More?), Jan Jansz Mostaert, c. 1525 – c. 1530|work=Rijksstudio|publisher=[[Rijksmuseum]]|location=Amsterdam|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> though Saint Maurice, and [[Balthazar (Magus)|Balthazar]] of the Three Kings or [[Biblical Magi]], had long been usually portrayed as black.
==Subject== If it is a portrait of a specific real individual, it appears to be the earliest known such painting of a black man in European painting.<ref name=rijksmuseum/> The [[Rijksmuseum]], who own the painting, have said that it might be Christophle le More (Christopher the Moor), a black archer recorded at the court of the Habsburg emperor [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]].<ref name=rijksmuseum/> This theory could be supported by the badge of the Virgin on his cap, which would be a souvenir from a pilgrimage to [[Halle, Belgium|Halle]].<ref name=rijksmuseum/> He has also been said to be a member of the entourage of [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy]] at her court in [[Mechelen]]. The posture, clothing and other details could indicate service at a European court and adaptation to their norms.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/recensies/rijksmuseum-koopt-portret-van-afrikaanse-man~a683831/ |title=Rijksmuseum koopt 'Portret van Afrikaanse man’ |language=Dutch |publisher=de Volkskrant |date=4 July 2005 |accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> The English historian Kate Lowe therefore argues he is a nobleman in the service of a visitor to the court at Mechelen, or such a visitor himself.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ernst van den Boogaart |url=http://www.groene.nl/artikel/een-portretwaardige-slaaf |title=Essay: een portretwaardige slaaf |language=Dutch |publisher=[[De Groene Amsterdammer]] |date=5 August 2005 |accessdate=24 January 2015}}</ref> Other scholars suggest that the insignia on his hat and bag may indicate possible Spanish or Portuguese origins.<ref name=LivCol>{{cite book|last=Jablonski|first=Nina|title=Living Color|year=2012|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, London|isbn=978-0-520-25153-3}}</ref>
In 2013, [[Wim Pijbes]], in a discussion on the Dutch folklore figure [[Zwarte Piet]] and his origins, mentions the ''Portrait of an African Man'', saying that the figure of Zwarte Piet is traceable to at least the 16th century, and the proud black figure depicted wearing a velvet jacket and a [[beret]] shows attributes nowadays associated with the figure of Zwarte Piet.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://nos.nl/artikel/565895-wie-is-die-zwarte-piet-eigenlijk.html |title=Wie is die Zwarte Piet eigenlijk? |language=Dutch |publisher=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]] |date=23 October 2013 |accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref>
In November 2014 a different explanation was offered by the literary and medieval scholar Marie-José Govers. She claimed the figure represented [[Saint Maurice]], a Roman soldier who by tradition came from [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]].<ref name=nrc>{{cite web|author=Marie-José Govers |url=http://www.nrc.nl/handelsblad/van/2014/november/07/niet-zwarte-piet-mauritius-in-rijks-1435497 |title=Niet Zwarte Piet, Mauritius in Rijks |language=Dutch |publisher=[[NRC Handelsblad]] |date=7 November 2014 |accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> Govers was to publish her research in 2015 but did so earlier to refute the remarks of Pijbes. She said that the figure depicted was an important man, not a servant. She bases this on the [[goatskin (material)|goatskin]] gloves, the belt which is covered with gemstones and the sword. She also adds that the sword is especially an attribute of Saint Maurice and that the [[pilgrim badge]] of Mary on his red beret makes him a Catholic. Govers adds that the time when the painting was made is also important. Govers claims this to be between 1520 and 1525 (disagreeing with the Rijksmuseum's view that the latter is about the earliest likely date).<ref name=rijksmuseum/> During that period [[Martin Luther]] was seen as a threat to the Catholic ruler Charles V. Luther was excommunicated by the Pope in 1520. Struggles between Catholics and Protestants were often violent. The depiction of Saint Maurice, a Christian who refused to fight against other Christians, could be related to this.<ref name=nrc/>
The art historian and curator Esther Schreuder disagrees with Govers's findings, stating that the evidence presented by Govers is too meager. Schreuder claims the sword is a typical symbol for a soldier and that Saint Maurice is most often depicted with a holy spear.<ref>{{cite web|author=Esther Schreuder |url=https://estherschreuder.wordpress.com/2014/11/09/st-mauritius-en-het-portret-van-mostaert/ |title=St Mauritius en het portret van Mostaert |language=Dutch |publisher=estherschreuder.wordpress.com |date=9 November 2014 |accessdate=26 January 2015}}</ref>
==Saint Maurice== Saint Maurice was very often depicted as a black soldier in northern Europe, and the years just before Mostaert's painting had produced such depictions in [[altarpiece]]s by the leading artists [[Matthias Grünewald]] (c. 1517–23) and [[Lucas Cranach the Elder]] (1522–25).<ref>[[:File:Mathis Gothart Grünewald 011.jpg|The Grünewald]] and [[:File:Lucas Cranach d.Ä. - Der heilige Mauritius.jpg|the Cranach]]</ref> But the small size of the Mostaert is more typical of a personal portrait.
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Saint Maurice Magdeburg.jpg|Statue of [[Saint Maurice]], around 1250, [[Magdeburg Cathedral]], Germany File:Meister Theoderich von Prag 024.jpg|[[Saint Maurice]] by [[Master Theoderic]], 1360s File:Lucas Cranach d.Ä. - Der heilige Mauritius.jpg|[[Lucas Cranach the Elder]] (1522-25) File:Mathis Gothart Grünewald 011.jpg|[[Matthias Grünewald]] (c. 1517-23)
</gallery>
==History== The painting was bought from art dealer [[Robert Noortman]] by the Rijksmuseum in June 2005 with financial support of amongst others the [[Rembrandt Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.verenigingrembrandt.nl/ul/cms/attachment/file/document/5/8/7/587/587/1/portret-van-een-afrikaanse-man.pdf |title=Portret van een Afrikaanse Man |language=Dutch |publisher=Vereniging Rembrandt |date= |accessdate=24 January 2015}}</ref> After the purchase the painting was exhibited in the [[Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen]] for some years due to renovations to the Rijksmuseum.<ref name=rijksmuseum/>

{{For|the blues musician|R. L. Burnside}} '''Robert Hubberthorne Burnside''' (August 13, 1873 – September 14, 1952)<ref>Scotlandspeople.org statutory birth records</ref> was an American actor, director, producer, composer, and playwright.<ref name=Timesobit/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=wB8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA51 "R. H. Burnside"], ''[[Billboard (magazine)|The Billboard]]'', September 27, 1952, accessed December 30, 2014</ref> He was artistic director of the 5,200-seat [[New York Hippodrome]] from 1908 to 1923. He wrote and staged hundreds of dramas, musicals and theatrical spectacles.<ref name=Timesobit/>
==Early life and education== Burnside was born in [[Glasgow|Glasgow, Scotland]]. His father was George Burnside, a manager of the Gaiety Theatre in Glasgow. His mother was Margaret Thorne, an actress, whose father was William Hubberthorne, a theatre proprietor. His siblings were Janet Agnes (born about 1853), John, Ann R., Isabella, and George. Burnside attended the Great Yarmouth Academy.<ref name=Timesobit>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1952/09/15/84356040.pdf "R. H. Burnside, 82, Producer, Is Dead. Former General Director of Old Hippodrome Staged 200 Shows During His Career"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 15, 1952, p. 25, accessed December 30, 2014 (payment required)</ref><ref>[http://archives.nypl.org/the/21994 R. H. Burnside collection], [[New York Public Library]], accessed December 30, 2014</ref>
== Career == As a child Burnside traveled on theatrical tours with his mother.<ref>Stephenson, William. "Burnside, R. H." in ''American National Biography Online'', accessed 6 January 2009.</ref> His first stage appearance was as a dog in ''[[The Bohemian Girl]]'' in a royal command performance, starring [[Edward O'Connor Terry]], before the [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|Prince of Wales, later King Edward VII]].<ref name=Timesobit/>
According to his passport application,<ref>Available at Ancestry.com</ref> he arrived in New York in October 1894, invited by [[Lillian Russell]] to direct her productions. Beginning in 1900, he directed [[musical theatre]] at the [[New York Hippodrome]] and at other [[Broadway theatre]]s. He was artistic director of the 5,200-seat [[New York Hippodrome]] from 1908 to 1923. He composed the scores, wrote the librettos for, and directed the Broadway productions ''The Tourists'', ''Fascinating Flora'' (which he also produced), ''Jack o' Lantern, Happy Days, [[Good Times (musical)|Good Times]], Tip Top'' and ''Better Times''. ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised his book for the musical ''Miss Billions'' in 1919.<ref>Woollcott, Alexander. [https://www.nytimes.com/1919/12/10/archives/the-play-more-musical-comedy.html "More Musical Comedy",] ''The New York Times'', December 10, 1919</ref> He was the librettist and director for ''A Trip to Japan'' (1909, which he also produced), ''The International Cup, Chin Chin, Hip Hip Hooray!, The Big Show, Cheer Up, Everything, Stepping Stones'', and ''Three Cheers''. He also directed the Broadway productions of others' works, such as ''[[The Emerald Isle]]'' (1902), ''[[The Earl and the Girl]]'' (1905) and many others. He joined ASCAP in 1914 as a charter member and collaborated with such composers as [[Raymond Hubbell]] and [[Gustave Kerker]]. His most famous songs were "You Can't Beat the Luck of the Irish", "Ladder of Roses", "Nice to Have a Sweetheart" and "Annabelle Jerome". In 1935, 1942 and 1944, he staged many revivals of [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] operas on Broadway.
The recording "The Ladder of Roses" from ''Hip-Hip-Hooray'' (1916)<ref>Released as Columbia A-2057</ref> is not just a rendering of the song but documents a supposed rehearsal with Burnside in charge. He offers pointed and humorous criticism of the women's chorus, which finally sings the song's refrain at the recording's conclusion. During the course of Burnside's near-monologue, he introduces [[double entendre]]s referencing some of the notable Hippodrome shows such as ''Chin-Chin,'' ''Stop, Look, Listen'' and ''Cheer-Up''. Here are two brief excerpts:
:BURNSIDE: How many absences Mr. Stewart? Only one? Ah – Cleopatra Cassidy again! Wonder what the excuse will be this time. I suppose she's had a fire in her house and she's waiting for the engines to arrive. Ah, here she is now. Good morning, Cleopatra. What's the trouble this time? Subway tied up again? No? Well, what happened? You're fifteen minutes late and everybody's waiting for you. What's that?
:CLEOPATRA: Had some trouble with my motor again!
:BURNSIDE: Well, you'll have some trouble with your salary again at the end of the week. Now come along everybody and let's get this rehearsal started. (''choristers start talking noisily among themselves'') Stop talking girls! This isn't a suffragette meeting.
Another excerpt: "Now stop, look, and listen all of you. The singing last night was awful. You must pay more attention to the musical director. All except you, Agnes – you're paying too much attention to him. If you don't stop it, I'll call his wife's attention to you!" This recording was reissued on CD in the 1990s on the set ''Music from the New York Stage, 1890–1920''<ref>Pearl GEMM CDS 9056-8, vol. 3 (disc 2, track 17).</ref>
In 1924, he directed the film ''[[Manhattan (1924 film)|Manhattan]]''.<ref>[https://uk.imdb.com/name/nm0122944/ R. H. Burnside] at the IMDB database</ref>
Burnside was the Shepherd (president) of [[The Lambs]] club from 1918 to 1921.<ref name=lamb>Hardee, Lewis J., Jr. [https://books.google.com/books?id=i9ujp_4nUEkC&printsec=frontcover ''The Lambs Theatre Club''], Jefferson, North Carolina: McFarland Publishing, 2010 [2006], p. 120. {{ISBN|978-0-7864-6095-3}}.</ref>
== Personal life == In 1905, Burnside married Katherine. The couple had three daughters, Catherine, born about 1907, Helen Marguerite, born March 1, 1912, and Betty, born about 1914.<ref>Based on information supplied to the 1920 and 1930 United States Federal Census, available on Ancestry.com. Catherine is not listed in the 1930 census.</ref> Helen married George Edward Blewitt on September 21, 1935.<ref>"Blewitt-Burnside," ''New York Times'', September 22, 1935, p. N5.</ref> Burnside was the president (Shepherd) of [[The Lambs]], a theatrical club, from 1918 to 1921.<ref name=lamb/> Burnside became a naturalized American citizen in Manhattan on July 3, 1917.<ref>See Naturalizations, Southern District, [http://www.Italiangen.org ItalianGen].</ref> His wife Katherine died in 1940.<ref>William Stephenson, "Burnside, R. H." in ''American National Biography Online'', accessed 6 January 2009.</ref>
Burnside died at the Middlesex Nursing Home in [[Metuchen, New Jersey]].<ref name=Timesobit/>
== Legacy == Because of his position as director and producer at the Hippodrome, Burnside inherited the legacies of Charles Dillingham and [[Charles Frohman]]. Upon his death, the material – including an extensive correspondence, business records, scripts, costume designs and other material – was donated to The [[New York Public Library]]. There the business records and correspondence are in the Manuscripts Division; scripts, production notes and designs are in the Billy Rose Theatre Division, and musical scores are held in the Music Division.

__NOTOC__ [[Image:Shemahinskaya boyaderka 2.jpg|right|thumb|150px|A dancer from [[Shamakhi]]. [[Grigory Gagarin|G.Gagarin]], mid-19th century]] The '''Shamakhi dancers''' ([[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]]: ''Şamaxı rəqqasələri'') were the principal dancers of the entertainment groups that existed in [[Shamakhi]] ([[Azerbaijan]]) up to the late 19th century. These groups worked similarly to [[tawaif]]s. [[Russia]]n painter [[Grigory Gagarin]] who lived in the [[Caucasus]] in 1840–1855 depicted the Shamakhi dancers in a series of paintings, in which he referred to them as ''bayaderki''[http://www.azeri.ru/az/cultur/359/ Ими восхищался Дюма] by Emil Karimov and Mehpara Aliyeva. ''Azeri.ru'' (баядерки; sg. ''bayaderka'' – баядерка; originally the Portuguese term ''balliadera'' borrowed into Russian and other European languages via French (''bayadère'') and initially used to refer to the [[devadasi]].Bayadère. Oxford English Dictionary. Retrieved February 1st, 2008 from Oxford English Dictionary.) The extant documents regarding the Shamakhi dancers, and dances, are very limited. In literature, Shamakhi dancers are referred to in [[Arthur Gobineau|Comte de Gobineau]]'s novel ''The dancing girl of Shamakha and other Asiatic tales''. ''The Dancer of Shamakha'' recounts the life of Armenian dancer [[Armen Ohanian]], her education as a dancer, her childhood in Russia, and her travels in Iran and Egypt. It was published in French as ''La Danseuse de Shamakha'' in 1918 and translated into English in 1923 by [[Rose Wilder]]. After moving to Europe, Ohanian danced traditional dances for audiences, gave lectures on poetry, and was an active member in intellectual and political circles. She eventually moved to Mexico. She is the author of some 15 publications including autobiographical volumes and books on culture and politics.Ohanian, Armen. ''La Danseuse de Shamakha''. Forward by Anatole France. (Harcourt, Brace and Company, New York, 1926), OCLC 220571590; 368 p. (Kessinger Publishing, Montana, 2007), {{ISBN|1-4325-7982-7}} *Ohanian, Armen. ''La Danseuse de Shamakha''.
